It is a good thing I notice far more than any pixels. It is just as good as all the TV's in my house and my iPad/iPhone, if not better in some aspects.When watching videos, it's definitely a thing you need to get into the habit for, as putting on the headset is a bit time consuming rather than just turning on a TV and sitting down. Until further improvements (which have been confirmed by Oculus to come in 2020 or sooner) are made for tracking, it is near impossible to watch videos at night, which discourages using it, because it needs to use the cameras and know where it is, and where the controllers are. This means keeping a light on, or having a really bright night light. The improvements Oculus are bringing for this issue will be astounding for other programs. The improvements include better tracking at night for controllers, and the ability to track hands so there is no need for controllers, which solves most issues and provides a true VR experience. Cannot wait for this. However until then, watching and playing at night or without any lights is impossible, so if you plan on doing that, wait a while; or don't! It's still fantastic.While I watch videos and movies and TV shows, the audio is great, the screen is great, and the feeling of a ginormous TV in front of you is great. However the best thing in my opinion is how comfortable it is.It's made of fabrics and soft straps, with no plastic pieces or heavy parts. It is still relatively heavy, but compared to other headsets, it's a dream. The weight balance is acceptable, and the straps are never uncomfortable. Watching stuff with this does not make my head hurt like the PSVR does, it's snug but not too snug.About the controllers, I like them. It took some time getting used to them, from other large controllers, but the responsiveness and little quirks about the controllers are wonderful. Just wish the straps wouldn't give out on me, they stopped tightening properly after about 2 months of regular use.The game selection is not very wide right now, but that's ok. The thing came out in May, and it has stuff like Beat Saber and SuperHot, so it's got the fun in those secured. However more quality titles are nowhere to be seen (yet!), and hopefully Oculus is able to bring big games like Minecraft VR, Skyrim VR, Borderlands VR, Etc. All over, because playing those on a PSVR or PCVR is not preferred after getting this headset, due to the fact that it's wireless.The wireless functionality has been the key factor for me. This thing is crazy cool and a humungous step in the right direction for VR. While the battery of the headset won't get you much playtime (2-3 hours, from experience) it sure does give me plenty of time to play wirelessly before plugging in the nonintrusive cable, trick for those wondering - play with the cord plugin into a wall behind you, and run the cord between your legs up to the headset, you won't even notice the charging cord there.As for the portability aspect. This is 1,000% better than anything else for letting friends and family try truly good VR without hauling a full PS4, or hauling a laptop (which most people don't use for VR, a desktop is smarter). I frequently bring this over to others and can hold the whole thing with one hand while carrying anything else I want in the other. I just use the original box it came in. Works fine for me! It's a great party trick, and not a one trick pony. People WILL ask you to bring this over when you visit, if they've tried it and liked it. People WILL ask when you'll bring it next. It doesn't get annoying, but it's funny! Seeing others try VR for the first time (and not garbage phone VR cases) with no wires, no limits, and with a good quality screen + good tracking, it is a wonderful way to pave the love of VR into everyone and get them hooked. I just wish there was a better way for everyone else to watch someone playing a game in VR. The current situation is having your friend put on the headset, with no custom headphones (using the built in speaker audio thingies) go to your phone, go to the Oculus app, and stream the Oculus view onto your phone. There is no audio (as far as I'm aware) transmitted to this cast, which is why I recommend the friend does not wear headphones, because the headset speakers themselves are the only way both the audience and player can hear what's going on. Not to mention the viewing for the audience is on a phone screen. You can cast your phone to a TV, but the lag from an internet connection, and high latency causing long delays onto a TV can make you feel like you're watching images of pixels with bad audio. There absolutely needs to be a revamped casting system for the quest, and I'm sad this is the best method!Unfortunately my first experience was with a phone VR case, and while I loved the concept of VR, it was a poor example for a first impression. I'm glad I stuck around for VR but not everyone is the same, this is a good way to get someone to try out VR and like it.Overall: There are some quirks and downsides. The battery isn't the best, more games could come out, nightime use can drastically improve, and the ability to cast properly are all things that I disliked or was not very happy about. However, the pros heavily outweigh the cons, and I am in no way going to get rid of this bad boy! It is a revolutionary product with many amazing features and a wonderful step for VR into the mainstream audience. If you're reading this and considering, absolutely do. It is worth every penny, especially since it's dirt cheap for the amount of use you'll be getting from it. I would do 9/10 but there are only 5 stars. So 4.5/5!
review_title: Best VR leap since the invention of VR!

one_reviews_text: Recommended mods: Deluxe Audio Strap is an absolute must. -- No way around it.  It will hurt your neck and head if you don't install this mod.Mamut Grips (or similar) are also kind of a must -- they let you let go of the controllers, and they just become a part of your hands -- your fingers move in IRL, they move in game. -- You don't have to grip the controllers the whole time.Rechargeable controllers -- this is a nice to have -- but just search for rechargeable USB batteries and small mini-right angle connectors for them. -- You can dremel out a small hole in the battery cover, so that the wire can come out and down and out of the bottom of the mamut grips. -- Then you can just plug in your controllers and have them always charged.Tactical Airsoft Helmet Counterweight -- lots of people are using all sorts of things for counter weights, including batteries -- but this has worked well for me; just put some velcro on the back of the DAS, and stick one of these to it, and you're good to go.  The nice thing about the airsoft counterweights is that you can calibrate them by removing/adding the little metal lego bricks.  Mine has spots for 5 of them and I use between 2 and 3.There's lots more mods you can do but those are the best ones, IMO.FYI, you can play PCVR games wirelessly with this headset using programs like Riftcat or Virtual Desktop (this has been there since like the second or third week after launch, can't remember).
review_title: You need to mod it, but it's great.

one_reviews_text: This is my second Oculus VR set I have owed.  First was the GO and now the QUEST.  I am not a gamer.  I have never owned a XBox or any other system.  I have had this unit for over a month and these are my comments.  I bought the quest so I could be free to move around and have a greater experience and the Quest does not fail.  I have had no issues with my unit remembering different lay outs.  Graphics are incredible, the sound is really good (although head phones are the way to go.  No bugs or lag times  to report when system starts.  The hand controllers are easy to use with several extra buttons for the system to grow into.  Better life on headset is about 2.5 hours.  Headset is a little awkward after the first hour, especially in the back, top.  I’m sure 3rd parties are working on this.  There are many games to choose from ranging from Free to $29.00.  There are moves, videos, porn, And games to choose from that will keep you busy..  5G speed will only make VR and AR more popular next yearI gave the quest 4 stars because the games are to expensive.  I was a little upset to find out my games purchased on GO could not be transferred over, or at least a discount given.  The headset awkward pressure points and battery life all add up to one less star.
review_title: Oculus Quest gets 4 out of 5 stars

one_reviews_text: I purchased this with the intention of eventually using it for PC VR purposes (once that feature was announced). The quest's ability to function independently from a PC but also having the capability to function as a PC VR headset was what led me to make the purchase. Looking at reviews, it would appear that unless you're a VR Snob, you'll likely not notice the difference. For the price, I'm not sure it could be beat right now.To be honest, though, so far I've not used the PC VR ability.So far, I've been mostly using it for fitness. I've purchased only two games so far: Pistol Whip and BoxVR. Pistol Whip, in a nutshell is a shooting game that acts as my leg day and BoxVR, is a boxing game that works my upper body. Running through just one of the games will generally give me a better workout than a 30 minute ride on a stationary bike. The game aspect allows me to work, without getting bored, for an hour or more if my endurance will allow. My best workout so far (according to my fitness tracker) burned nearly 1000 calories and peaked my heart rate at about 189 bpm. This is fantastic, especially if you live somewhere where inclement weather doesn't allow you to get outside for a run. Likewise, if you're like me and get bored working out, the game aspect keeps me engaged.I do not own any other headset to compare this to so I am unable to give you a solid comparison, other than knowing I'm able to run the games from the Oculus store and don't need to be plugged into a fairly expensive PC. You can take it anywhere. Show it to friends, show it off at a party, take it to work and get a workout in on your lunch break if you've got somewhere to use it (That's what I do).Protips:Buy a lenscover, they shouldn't be more expensive than 10 bucks.Buy a face cover of some sort. The stock one is generally fine to start unless you're using it for fitness and get sweaty easily (I do).If you squeeze the controllers too hard the battery cover might slide off. Buying a cover for them or some scotch tape will help.(I was able to buy all three of the above in a package on amazon for about 25 bucks)After owning it for about a week, I bought a case for it since I take it to and from work. It's not that I mishandle it, it's that a case costs about 25 bucks and the 64GB Quest was still expensive (for me). 25 extra bucks protects it. Harbor Freight carries an Apache Case listed for about that (With a coupon). The Quest and controllers will fit neatly inside it.There are a host of customization options for the Quest. Everything from decals for the front, aftermarket head straps... etc. All of them are pretty innovative and more seem to pop up every week.One complaint I've seen is that there are a lack of games (on the Oculus store) for the quest at the moment. However I would point out that the Quest has only been around about a year and with it constantly being sold out, it would show the demand for games is there. Likewise developers are scrambling to come up with new and exciting content, both for the Quest and for the PC VR market. I would also note that, at the moment, there are developer options that can allow you to access other features or in development games. I would also argue that since it can use the PC VR function, if you get a computer capable of supporting that feature, your game library access expands exponentially.If you have other questions about the Quest or are curious about what accessories are best, there are a host of Youtube personalities who have already been there. Lookup "BMF" or "Eric For President" or "Virtual Reality Oasis" or "Cas and Chary VR" since most of them have tried the accessories or games out and you can watch them show you what they're all about and tell you if they're actually worth the money. There are countless others too, the Apache Case I found from the youtube channel "Tyco Tech."In all: 5 Stars. It does exactly what I want and more. I'm very pleased with this product.
review_title: Fantastic for games and Even great for fitness

one_reviews_text: So first of all, I'm a big time video gamer so when I started hearing about the Quest I really, really wanted one. For my 50th birthday this year, I bought myself one. And well, let's just say I live in Virtual Reality now. Or at least I want to. I can't even describe how awesome this thing is. I wanted to check out the Internation Space Station app which is free and my god, it's so mindblowing. I live in a tiny hut in the Shire, so to be transported to space and to get to do space walks felt like I had escaped into wonder. I almost burst out, "They should have sent a poet" ala Jodie Foster in Contact, but I digress. The next thing I did was download Vader Immortal and, after playing though the game with fricken' Darth Vader right in front of me, I decided to spend some time in Vader's Dojo. Let's just say I'm there every night fighting with a lightsaber and getting a wee bit of cardio. Seriously, if you're a geek like me, this thing will change your life. Come to the Dark Side people!

I am not what you’d call a gamer. I have a PS4 and play video games w my kids. Bought this on a whim, and it is mind blowing. All my family and friends have tried it, and even the most skeptical among them have said “oh my GOD” after a few minutes. The system is so smooth, the controller tracking is flawless, and the games are great. My kids love it. I love it.I have only three gripes: 1) the battery life on some intense games is a little low. Sometimes dies after 2 hours. Believe me, it’s very easy to play this system for two hours straight. 2) most games only allow one player profile, so if you’re using the headset for multiple people in a household, you all have to basically share the same progress in every game. Sort of annoying. 3) controllers should be rechargeable. They eat about two AA batteries per week.That being said, I love this thing. I would buy it again and again. It’s easy to use, and it is like nothing else I’ve ever played. It is like you are actually inside the games you’re playing. We love the Star Wars game, Job Simulator, and Racket. But all the games we’ve bought have been awesome.Our PS4 has been almost totally idle since buying the oculus. First thing out of my kids’ mouths when they get home from school is “can we play the oculus?!?”

It took a few weeks to get this after ordering because it was backordered, but it was worth the wait. I've never had a VR system and I understand that this is not quite as technically advanced as something like the Rift; it has a lower-powered processor than the Rift, which from what I understand results in slightly lower resolution and processing speed, but so far I'm completely blown away! The headset is somewhat weighty, but with some adjustment I find it to be fairly comfortable. The controllers are responsive. The Guardian system that allows you to set play space boundaries so you don't bump into things is spot-on, though I wish there was a button to project it at any point, instead of having to get close to it for the barrier grid to show up on the screen. Casting to another device took a bit of work, as the instructions aren't exactly clear, but I got it working. A complaint there is that there is a distracting red dot that shows up in your field of vision to show that you're casting, but it's only slightly to the upper right of your vision; it could definitely be placed further out to it's less intrusive, or even having an option to disable it altogether. It seems that a number of folks have this opinion, and Oculus does have forums where you can suggest future upgrades to the devs.As to the game catalog, there are a number of fun and interesting titles, several of which I can tell greatly benefit from being untethered to a computer. It would be nice if there were more demos so you can try them out before buying; as of now there are only two or three, and a few more non-game experiences would be welcome, but the thing has only been out a few months so I suppose we should give it time. I'm definitely excited to see what games come out in the future, but so far there are some good titles available.One big question I had when considering which to buy was the memory: should I get the 64 or 128GB? I can tell you that I currently have 5 or 6 games and a few apps/experiences loaded, with a fair bit of room left over. And of course, as you complete games you can always delete and then reinstall them later, so I feel that spending the extra $100 for the extra GBs isn't really worth it; save that money to buy some games.In the end, I would say that if you're thinking about buying this or the Rift, you should consider if the lower resolution is a big factor (though I don't think it's that big of a difference, but I could be wrong since I've never used a Rift), and if you're OK being wired into a PC, reducing your range of motion. But if none of that matters to you and you're willing to plunk down $400 on a gaming system, buy this. Buy it now. You may have to wait for it to be in stock and delivered, but it's like being a kid waiting for Christmas again. I fully believe this is the future of VR gaming and will lead to further developments that will make VR more mainstream. I am extremely happy with my purchase, and highly recommend it!

Mixed feelings... won’t play with steam and you need to buy 3rd party streaming software to play games from pc.  It only plays “app” style games so if you Are wanting to steam you VR games you already own they will not work.  Even loading games you already own that can loaded onto the device requires the purchase of more 3rd party software.  It’s not very user friendly if you want to play games you have already bought and they oculus App Store doesn’t have a lot of quality games. Mainly B or C rated indie games. Also it does offer an almost open source web browser and fire fox but for an android based device not having a Google app in the store or available for download and having to download it though once again a 3rd party software is almost  laughable. It does have some great features like the tracking and not needing external sensors. The hardware is exactly what VR headsets need don’t get me wrong it’s great. they just need to focus more on software improvements. If it was compatible with mainstream gaming and didn’t require 2 different 3rd party software to stream and load it would have gotten 4 stars.

$400 is a lot of money for me. I bought it for 2 reasons - one is the health aspect and I have friends who are using it as their primary source for working out. The second and, equally important, reason I bought it is for meditation. When I heard there were meditation apps I was happy because I imagined meditating in all kinds of beautiful environments.I went to the Quest app store, only to find there are only 4 apps, ranging from $9.99 to $14.99. I tried one and liked it, but am disappointed in the limited selection. In fact, as I browsed the store, I was disappointed in the hefty prices for most apps. Free apps are limited...I only found16 in my search. After spending $400, I didn't count on having to spend so much on content.As for the headset, even with the eyeglass piece inserted, I found my lenses were not sitting in a way that gave me the sharpest viewing experience. (Just ordered new glasses, so this may be an issue just for me - we'll see.)So, overall, after the initial sticker shock, I see apps I would like to try but man, this is an expensive endeavor. After all of that expense, I expected a lot of free content and I am just not seeing it.Now I have learned there is another way to get apps called SideQuest, which means downloading APK files on the web, transfer them to the Oculus Quest, install them, then launch the app without using the Oculus Library. Ummm, ok.Additionally, I find the headset to be cumbersome and heavy. I used it sitting in bed for the meditation app, but still need to try it for active exercise. A lot to learn and figure out, but not sure this is something I can afford in the long run. Disappointing.
review_title: So far, a little  disappointed in the value

one_reviews_text: Being Oculus customer service is so horrible contcting them is useless a week and no reply, the unit I got died the first use, I have a temp reader and it read 115F. Now I am not technician at Oculus but that is not healthy for anything to have near the eye. I was trying to setup the unit it was on 15min but would not finish the setup, I thought it was hot in my house and took the headset off to amazingly hot, over hot Crap its hot unit.  Oculus has zero support so boxed the piece of junk and sent it back, if you have similar issues. Return it, these are not safe if they can get that hot.Hard to rate anything else since it was defective and nearly burned to the touch.Just found out its not compatble with Steam?? Wow.Oculus Seller, please do not comment to contact you as you do not help, only send generic answers forcing a return. So unless you are going to send me a free unit for my trouble, I wont be using Oculus products again, the GO over heated and so does the Quest.
review_title: Avoid, 115F over heat. The issues that plagued Go plauge Quest AVOID

one_reviews_text: The Quest is by far my favorite console and iv been ignoring my xbox for months! Oculus is doing a great job so far and facebook to! The games are ever increasing with better and better on the way! Cant wait to play Arizona sunshine and death lap! Facebook horizon looks good to! After i purchased my Quest a week later my brother got one! If you see any complaints its usually gamers who have a gaming pc and have known about vr and have a certain standard. Or people looking at quest as underpowered and little content. Well its BRAND NEW and is gonna be walking before it sprints! I can tell you the content comes quickly! Had only a handfull of games and now the library will be hit with great games in december we are seeing many! So. If you want to experience wireless VR games. And dont have a PC, or just want it wireless. Its the Headset/console to get. Plus it has LINK so you can plug into PC at any time if you have it. Join us Questers! And know the popular VR gameplay you have been Binge watching on youtube! We have a very active facebook group just look up ARNOOKIE and other Oculus quest community-based pages! This is Cody blaze K. if anyone from our group recognizes throw a thumbs up so the new people can see! Can't wait for the new comers that we need to make our VR games great!

Really wanted to like the quest. So many glowing reviews. The convenience compared to prior generation VR setups is game-changing.But they quest couldn't figure out where my floor was, so I had to put big QR codes all over the room with masking tape so the quest could "see" my floor. Ugh.And then, great, tracking seems to work, ish. What games does it come with? None? Wait, what? Ugh.Well, let's look into my oculus account and download my prior purchased games...Wait, *none* of my purchases work on the quest? I have to buy everything all over again? Ugh.Let's try the space pirate trainer demo. Ok, neat, but lag spikes make for nausea. And I can't put my hands behind or below me, as my controller disappears. Ugh.Had teenage son try it out, and he was nauseous after a couple minutes. "It looks nice, Dad, but I'm never putting that back on." Ugh.Too many ughs. Back it goes.
review_title: Inside-out tracking is spotty. Lag spikes lead to nausea.

one_reviews_text: I have both  - original rift and quest. So I'm comparing it to the rift only.Cons:1. Quest is very uncomfortable, it's impossible to wear it for more than 30 min, it's heavy and all the weight goes to your face! I do not have such problem with rift at all.2. VR sickness, it's much worse than with a rift. I don't know the reason, may be inaccurate tracking or low refresh rate 72Hz. Rift has 90Hz.3. Image quality, frankly I don't see any huge improvement over rift. Yes, it's better but not even x2 times better.4. Audio - garbage.Pros:1. Inside-out tracking, this is a pretty cool feature, but I doubt they will get a high precision tracking with it, it involves image recognition which is computationally expensive and inaccurate, unlike simple lighthouse tracking which used by vive and valve headsets. I know, it's portable but cmon, 99% of its users are using it in the same places.2. Oculus link, allows you to play games from SteamVR and Oculus Rift.I wish Carmack and his engineering team come up with better ergonomics, lighthouse tracking and minimum 90Hz refresh rate.

I bought the Rift S instead of this at launch day, preordered. I was on the fence between both units... I returned the rift S. It was terrible!!!! I waited to buy the Quest afterwards actually it was so bad. Until I heard about the Oculus Link technology and witnessed first hand ALVR running PC VR on a Quest.... Bought one, I love it, Best thing ever!!!!!  Adding hand tracking soon along with the Link make this a no brainer!  The Rift S is dead!  This becomes a Rift Q with a good USB 3.0 cable. or wireless with ALVR like I said. One pro tip I can give you all though. instead of connecting to your local wifi network. buy a good USB 3.0 wifi dongle. and then create a hotspot network in windows withit. Conect to your hotspot via the quest and make sure your PC is wired to your network instead of wireless. but that last part is not a big deal with this method actually. But doing this will remove any network latency or traffic from your wifi. Simply go into your hardware settings for your wifi card and manually set it to 40 mhz and to only use 802.11 a/n/c or any combo of those otherwise the hotspot will default to b/g mode which you don't want. If you do this you can play ALVR wireless PC VR no problem! It's literally amazing!!!!! don't listen to the other methods. do it this way.
review_title: better than a rift s and mobile

one_reviews_text: A pixel 2 XL with cardboard vr is 100 times better. So disappointed. UI is terrible. Getting started with any app is garbage. Screen door effect is bad. The ring effect is bad. No forward and back adjustment is an epic fail. Even when it's "off" the battery ran out... Spying much Facebook? Avoid. 💯% crap.
review_title: An old cell phone and cardboard is better. Sad.

one_reviews_text: Purchased for our daughter for Christmas 2019.  I thought since this was a Facebook company, the quality would be good.  My daughter likes the game.  Unfortunately, after five months of usage,  the right controller stopped working.  (my daughter does not play on the game everyday - the failure is not from excessive use).I googled support and found this issue has happened to quite a few people.  There are entire reddit threads dedicated to this issue.  We followed the suggestions and still could not get it to work.  We tried everything from changing batteries to resetting the device.Finally we contacted Oculus support and they opened a ticket. They said it appears we have tried all of the suggested repair protocols but with no luck.  They requested our purchase information and the serial numbers.  We have not heard from them since.  I would have expected better quality.  Buyer beware!
review_title: Poor Quality - Surprising given this is owned by Facebook

one_reviews_text: Well, it's like this...The Quest VR was amazing right up to the day it completely failed (26 days from the date of purchase) and upon research of the failure on the Oculus support site I found out that this exact issue (sudden loss of function of the home page, library, and store on the main control panel) has been a known issue since at least May and their suggestion to remedy the issue (simultaneously press the power button and volume control to reset the unit) killed the Quest. Luckily the failure happened prior to the expiration of return date and Amazon has ordered a replacement at no cost. The sad thing about my experience, even though I will receive a new unit, is that the failure issue has not been solved by Oculus.I can't express how "awesome" this technology is and how much I want my new quest to arrive, I just hope that the multibillion dollar organization that owns Oculus can fix this little bug.

I absolutely LOVED the original Oculus Rift, but the Quest and Rift S - I am not a fan. Those moments of presence in VR where you are jumping to return a tennis ball or quickly fire off an arrow: The tracking is often lost for a split second. It's not much, but enough to really make the experience less fun. Tracking also requires a ton of light to be effective. I'm so bummed that I was a proselytizing fan of Oculus, now I get angry every time I think about my experiences with Quest and Rift S.Doesn't require a PC to use, so that's something I guess ...

I’m a big gamer, and I had heard of VR technology but not experienced it until this past Christmas. My brother brought his Valve Index and gaming laptop to a family gathering and after 10 minutes in Blade & Sorcery I was hooked. The problem with other headsets like the Index is that they require expensive base stations and are wired to a gaming PC. Plus, the Valve is $1000. I did a lot of homework and settled on the Oculus Quest for $399 and I couldn’t be happier with my purchase.The Oculus Quest is a great ‘mid-range’ entry to VR and honestly in my opinion the best bang for your buck. The Oculus Quest is a completely wireless system. You put on the headset, turn it on, and are immediately thrown into setting up a guardian (play space) and playing immersive tutorials. It is intuitive and requires no other expensive hardware to enjoy the experience. This makes it very easy to share the experience with friends and family (low barrier of entry).The best part about the system? If you ARE a gaming enthusiast with a decent gaming rig, you can link your Oculus Quest to your gaming PC to play more graphics intensive games. You can do this through the new Oculus Link feature with a cable or even wirelessly with the Virtual Desktop app in the Oculus Quest App Store. The wireless setup takes a bit more hoops to jump through, but once setup it works fantastically. There are many tutorials online that explain how to do this.I can go to a family gathering and share Beat Saber with loved ones, but then come home, boot up my gaming rig, and play No Man’s Sky VR wirelessly in the office.This Oculus Quest really does offer the best of both worlds for the best price. Honestly, the 64Gb version is more than enough space. Don’t waste the extra $100. Most VR games are smaller in size and the more intensive games you will be running on a gaming rig anyways.One thing to note is that the Quest’s tutorials recommend kids be 13+ to play. This headset is an expensive piece of hardware that requires care. The Lens are easy to scratch if you don’t take care of them and the controllers won’t take a lot of abuse (punching walls, etc). Keep that in mind if you are looking to purchase the system for children.Also, the lens technology used can feel a tad ‘blurry’ when trying to read white text on a dark background. It results in a halo effect. From all of the research I have done online, all VR headsets are like this currently. It takes some getting used to.

The answer is yes and no, but mostly YES. The only downsides when compared to the PSVR is the refresh rate and the weight. But both of those cons are offset by what you gain. Namely the higher resolution and the quest being completely wireless. It is front heavy and you will feel the heft. It's not a dealbreaker but it's something you'll get used to. Adjust the straps properly and you'll be fine. The ease of use cannot be overstated. The setup for the unit and play area are easy as can be. The "intro" to get you used to the controls ran a bit long for me as I wanted to just get into the meat of the interface. The speakers on these are a revelation. So much so that I don't think I'll ever need to get ear/headphones. One less thing to put on my head!  As of this review, I do wish there were more games (something the PSVR has in spades for obviously being in the market longer), but what is there is enjoyable and worth owning the quest for. Another upgrade the quest has over the PSVR is the tracking. You don't need to face a camera and therefore tracking loss is kept to a minimum (if ever).  I love that it's completely portable so you can share the experience with friends and family outside of your home.Overall it's like a refined version of the PSVR but with a few tradeoffs to achieve the form factor and pricing.  I thought I was set with the PSVR, but I was really longing for that untethered VR experience. So glad I bought the Quest.
review_title: Is it an "upgrade" from a PSVR?

one_reviews_text: Edit, 12/28/20:I've had this device for nearly two years now and have a few more comments to make.  First, it's still a great first-gen standalone VR system, with the ability to play graphically-intensive games at a usually-decent frame-rate (expect frame-drops frequently, though).  I'm still rating this a solid 4 out of 5 stars.  It still has issues with smoothly running games with a stable frame-rate, with intermittent stuttering.  Honestly, it annoyed me enough to replace the system thrice (thanks, Oculus) to try and find a system that didn't stutter, but every one I've owned does to a degree.  Four "defective" devices in a row seems unlikely, so...I've finally come to accept it's just the limitations of the hardware, running all this stuff on a mobile VR system.  I wish that lightbulb had gone off sooner, as I feel kind of bad now for requesting replacements on something that isn't actually a bug, apparently.  So, keep in mind: If you want a lag-free mobile VR experience...sadly, it's still several years off, I think.Original review:I was lucky enough to receive my Quest on release day and immediately booted it up, having bought a ton of games earlier when the store opened.  Set-up was a breeze (only took about five minutes or so, maybe less), and then I was in First Steps.  Wow, what a cool experience!  I actually replay it on occasion (I love that you can do that!) because it's just so fun.  The controls were fairly intuitive and I find the experience of physically grabbing objects to be wonderful.  Coming from the Oculus Go, the 6 DOF for your two controllers is truly a game-changer.The addition of room-scale to VR is awesome!  I've only had Google Cardboard-like headsets and then the Go, so I had nothing to compare it to.  Wow.  Just...wow.  I play Super Hot daily and it still blows my mind that I can actually drop to the floor to dodge bullets and then roll behind cover!  I have started to use the Quest as an exercise device, with Beat Saber and Super Hot being my favorites (for a game where "time only moves when you move", Super Hot is a surprisingly intense workout).  I await the Quest 2 and will buy it day-one.So, for my glowing review, why four stars?  I'm not sure if my device is slightly defective or if I'm just sensitive to screen-tearing and stuttering, but I just can't ignore the stuttering that happens in (admittedly graphically-intense) games like Job Simulator and Drop Dead: Dual Strike.  For example, when loading up Office Worker in Job Sim, the environment lags a bit when moving around at times or when a lot of things are happening.  In Drop Dead, it's also present, to a noticeable degree.  Again, it in no way makes the Quest unusable, but I was immediately disappointed to spot flaws in my brand-new device.  Or is a certain amount of stuttering supposed to happen and expected?  I really don't know, as I've never played games this demanding on a stand-alone headset before.I don't know if it warrants a return or not.  Aside from the stuttering and glitches (my controllers lose tracking in Beat Saber with annoying frequency and reinserting the batteries doesn't fix it), the Quest is near-perfect and I have never had a gaming experience like it.  If I do return it, I'll buy another physically from a store, I think.  Just in case.
review_title: This is a top-notch product!  Aside from a bit of stuttering....

one_reviews_text: Being an early VR adopter and owning the CV1, I was scared of the graphical downgrade, and possibly worse tracking, on the Quest.But oooohhhhh boy, those are NOT a problem!The graphics may be worse but THE RESOLUTION IS AMAZING!  Almost NO GOD RAYS!  I can hardly block the tracking EVEN IF I TRY!  How on earth does it track me when I cover the cameras WITH MY HANDS?!  Amazing.  I mean, holding my hands over my head for a few seconds will cause it to lose tracking, but aside from that, I have never had, or at least noticed, a loss of tracking.  And it works just fine in dark rooms, after all.And you'd be amazed at how many games you can fit on the 64gb version.The only thing I don't like is that I can't seem to connect an external SSD to the device to watch movies...  No reason that shouldn't work.  Hopefully they add that feature soon, or else I might have to invest in a portable NAS.
review_title: Wow.  I actually don't notice the graphics!

one_reviews_text: Oculus done a great job making a VR headset wireless, but the titles and picture quality are just not good enough to support the price. I got mine on the release date and got bored playing it after a week or so. The reason is because there aren’t many good titles you can play. The most enjoyable title is beat saber, but i got bored after a while due to the lack of songs and it has tracking problem sometimes. The headset is quite heavy and it also freeze sometimes. All in all, VR technology is not mature yet...

The Quest VR:it is awesome and as I learn more about it, I enjoy it more. Game library is still currently small, BUT as of writing this, this system is only a year past release, so it's still growing. 120+ at the moment. Plus SideQuest stuff.For a stand alone, it's great. A little pricey, but still a good investment. The haptic response (vibration) in controllers is a huge thing with me. One of my fave game, Real VR Fishing, really gets you into it and while I haven't caught that damn shark yet, it's time is coming as my skills improve.If you want to play Half Life Alyx, you need the the link cable. I think party link is the cheapest. (Gaming pc is needed for steam games) but this CAN act like a Rift if u have the PC. I don't, so haven't tried this aspect of it.The seller:While the shipping was quick, my issue was price. I paid little over $500 for mine, in the week before it arrived, he continued to raise price to nearly $650 on his remaining sets. Price gouging on electronics was ridiculous when the quarantine started and I wasn't buying for that reason. I had a 4 month jump on quarantine before everyone else, just cause of my situation.My advice, look for the best price. Don't pay more than $550 for this. I saw some sets going for over $900 and that's just nuts. Do your research before buying.

Oh My God. That's the first thing pretty much everyone says the first time they try the Oculus Quest. It's a truly amazing experience.I bought my Quest as a family Christmas present last year. Okay, let's just say I bought myself a present last December and called it a family present. :-)  It's Beat Saber's fault. I swear.I'm not going to talk about all the good things. There are tons of people doing YouTube videos that can tell you about that. I'm only going to give you a couple of warnings and maybe a suggestion or two.-Warning one: the battery life is good (about 2 hours), but if you and some friends/family are playing, you can readily burn through that. There are ways to resolve that, including external batteries. See the various YouTube videos that talk about accessories.-Warning two: limit play time (initially). This wasn't just me. Playing too long at first can give people motion sickness, even on games rated Gentle. Once you've had it for a while (not all that long), this goes away.I'm also going to recommend you watch some of the YouTube accessory videos and spend a little more money. I haven't done it yet, but I recommend face shield things that can be more easily cleaned. You might get a little sweaty, and the next person might be grossed out by your sweat. You'll probably want a travel case. i bought the one from Oculus.And get rechargeable batteries for the controllers. You'll otherwise go through a LOT. I went with Amazon Basics. I got a 4-port charger and 4 batteries, so I always have 2 charged batteries waiting for me. Now, "a lot" isn't daily. The controller batteries last 3-7 days. But that's "a lot" if you use normal, non-rechargeable batteries.Different people will like different games. My favorite remains Beat Saber. It gets my fat old body moving. The space pirate battle trainer thing is fun, as is Gun Club VR. My adult daughters like Moss. I think that's a cute game, too, but I struggle with some of the puzzles. I'm old and slow or something, I guess.If you're having family parties, I tried sharing to my Apple TV via my iPhone. That worked, sort of, but it tends to drop out, and there's serious lag. I bought a Chromecast, and that works much better. It's the only thing we use the Chromecast for. Being able to let other people see the game is fun.

First, I love the actual experience of using the headset.  The experience is so much better than I even imagined.  The games are a bit expensive, but so far worth the expense.  However, the speaker on the right side has failed already, and I keep the sound turned way down.  It failed after less than 4 hours worth of use.  I can still use headphones so I haven't returned it, but for this amount of money, it should have lasted longer.  I would still recommend it for the experience, but I am a bit disappointed in the quality of the equipment.

Raise your hands if you've read this book more than three times like me?Needless to say the concept of VR described in the book and our virtual reality reality were far apart: an octopus of cables and sensors hooked up to a required $1.5k computer which few of us had. In the end, you ended up broke looking like Neo in his battery pod powering The Matrix. So when Quest was announced I thought, eureka!! I pre ordered and for once I was the first kid with the Atari 2600 on my block. In a word, glorious. The second word is "scary". The freedom that having no wires provides makes it almost too easy to go down a rabbit hole and lose entire days just playing, messing around and avoiding daylight.Many reviewers have already rattled off the technical pros and cons. There are more pros than cons. Is it perfect? What in this life is?? My face hurts from having this heavy piece of plastic and glass hugging my face for several hours. The battery runs down too quickly  (about two hours) . Yeah yeah, get a battery pack and enjoy yourself.The one major pro that is yet to be fully understood is that now you can hangout in "places" and experience "things" so frighteningly real that the teenage version of me would never have finished school or formed a family. It is a great system and the potential is truly astounding. Buy with confidence.

I really, truly, absolutely love this VR headset. It’s the first and only VR experience I’ve ever had, but it really is phenomenal. The only drawback is selection of games, and most games are more experiences than anything. That said, I love being able to invite friends over for their first VR experience and love to see their reactions to complete submersion.  Some really graphically impressive games have been released, and new and innovative tech and updates are constantly being added. This is, by far, the greatest gaming innovation since what I recall being a game stopper in my lifetime.  I’ve spent a bunch more $$$ in add-ons, including the HTC Vive headstrap, external battery pack, and a new face pad, and still this is a great deal. I’m so excited for newly released games and Oculus has simply been killing it with their support for this system. RECOMMENDED TO ANYONE AND EVERYONE!

[Edit] 10/21/2019I am going to up my rating to 4 stars. Oculus is doing a good job at listening to their Users. I wetn to https://oculus.uservoice.com/ and noticed others requesting the same. i also noticed they (Oculus) respond and show they are listening.If they do eventually go to a Multiple Profile OS I will bump it to 5 stars. This product is amazing outside of that. VR is amazing on this.(September 2019)I am not happy about this product but I do want to be fair with this review. So before I tell you why I gave this 2 stars let me say what is good about this product.The GoodThe VR is great. The device does a great job transporting you to a VR world with a great view and cozy fire place in the Menu Room. They selection of Apps is encouraging and I know the library is growing.I have had the PlaystationVR in the past and the tracking was so bad I got sick a lot. With the Quest I have had no issues with the tracking and my VR legs are getting strong.I also love the TV feature in the menu. This puts you in a comfy living room with a mountain view and a monster screen in front of you. From there you can watch ESPN and other TV Apps. It is nice if you want to watch something insulation from others. I just hope the selection of Streaming Apps does increase. Would love to see Youtube TV on this App.The Guardian System is really a brilliant idea. The headset has multiple I believe IR cameras and when you turn the system on it allows you to create a virtual wall to protect you from going too far in games and hurting yourself. if you go too far this virtual wall will appear in game warning you. And it seems to remember the room when you go back to the headset later.Now.... The Bad.Honestly it's just one thing and it is so big IMO I recommend holding off on purchasing this item until Oculus/Facebook address this issue.You can only have one User profile per device. If you want to let others in your house use it on their own profile you have to Factory Reset the device and start over. And!! That profile will have to buy the apps again if they want to play them. When you buy a game it is assigned to the profile not the device. This device was advertised as a Console VR system. This is not a console VR system. This is a personal device for one person by design.I bought this for my family and the way it is designed I would have to buy one for each member of my 7 member family..... Not a chance Facebook.This product has the chance to make VR popular. But not without the ability for multiple Profiles.
review_title: [Update]Product is great. Just needs Multiple Users.

one_reviews_text: First, let me start by saying that I love the Quest experience and games.  This is really is a top notch VR experience.  So, why the 1 star?  I have a Netgear Orbi, and wifi drops every 10-20 minutes forcing me to manually re-connect.  If you google this issue, you'll see that many others who use a mesh type network have this same issue.  Furthermore, they have been aware of this issue since it's inception, and it still hasn't been fixed.What that means for me is that I have to avoid buying any games that require an internet connection.  It's also a pain when downloading games, and there's no way I can watch a movie or do anything else with it until/if this issue is fixed.  And like many others, forget about trying to get any support.  I put in a support ticket over a week ago, and haven't had a response (they say 2 business days).If it weren't for this issue, I would rate the Quest 4 stars.  It wouldn't be a 5, because the other issue I have is that I wanted this for the whole family, but it's only tied to one account.  So, it does not lend itself to multiple users/accounts for games, making this device pretty much just for me only.So, if you don't have a mesh wifi network, I would very much recommend the Quest.  If you do, buyer beware!!!
review_title: Known Issue with Netgear Orbi/mesh wifi networks

one_reviews_text: Whether you're new to VR or are a long time enthusiast, the Quest is an amazing piece of technology.Having experience with a friend's PSVR and HTC Vive, I thought the technology was very cool, but a pain to set up. I always wanted VR, but it's too expensive for someone like me, who doesn't already have a PS4 or powerful PC. I don't really have much time for tethered consoles anymore, so it doesn't make sense for me to invest so much in something I would rarely be able to enjoy. After spending two years with my Nintendo Switch, I can't go back to trying to find time for console gaming.The Oculus Quest has finally made portable 6dof roomscale VR a reality without feeling like it's compromised too much. While there's a noticeable downgrade in graphics, the freedom from wires and the ability to turn any room into a play space more than makes up for it not being as powerful. Thankfully, the resolution is really high. It's higher than PSVR, or the original Rift/Vive. This, and the freedom of movement and wireless game play make it feel more immersive than console/PC VR.The games available, at the moment, are ports of many games that were previously only available on PC/PS4. It's amazing how well they look and run on mobile hardware. The difference between the Quest and PSVR/Vive feels very similar to the difference between PS4 and Switch games. It's a compromise I'm happy to make for an all-in-one VR game system.The Touch controllers are smaller than the PC counterparts, but work amazingly well. Many VR games were built around these controls, and apart from the smaller size work just as well.The inside out tracking and guardian system work almost flawlessly providing 1:1 tracking and a safe play space. Set up takes a minute, tops, and doesn't need any sensors.As someone who works at a group home nearly 70 hours a week, my overnights are now a time of respite. I can keep an ear out for my clients while feeling like I'm somewhere else. This has had such a theraputic effect that it literally feels life changing. I love my Nintendo Switch. It's awesome to be able to play console quality games anywhere, but the Quest gives me a change of scenery. It is also very helpful for someone with a sedentary lifestyle. I'm moving my body more and it feels great.I would highly recommend this to anyone with an interest in VR. It has the power to convert even people who don't play videogames regularly. We're living in the future, and it's awesome! I feel like I have a portable holodeck that's not only fun, but theraputic. I highly recommend the Oculus Quest. This could be just the device that will take VR from a niche hobby to a mainstream fixture in entertainment.
review_title: A Potentially Life Changing Game System

one_reviews_text: Got this for our son for Christmas this year.  He absolutely loves it and hasn't put it down since he opened it. Well except for the 2 hour or so battery life. The charger that comes with it charges very slow. He decided to use his fast charger from his macbook air and it charges it way faster.  It came with all three episodes of the Darth Vader game.  I tried it and like it as well.  The graphics are not xbox 1 quality but they arent Atari quality either. I bought him a travel case for it as well. Once the headphones come back in stock I will get those because I think the surround sound will be way better.  I think I will rig a battery pack to make the gameplay last longer. I would recommend it.  He would recommend it as well. I'm going to get a few more. A downside is only one person can be registered to it. If you want to add another family member you will have to reset it to factory defaults and clear out the other person. This will erase all their progress and games. However, you can play their games on their account if they let you. So if you have more than one child or adult that wants it they will have to have their own. There also isnt any multi player games out right now. We also purchased a warranty with it.

Oculus Quest is the best way to experience VR. However, quality control issues will ruin your experience.Pros:No PC neededFun games like beat saberFun exercise games like supernaturalAdjustable PDOculus Link for PC VR games too!Cons:Very Poor quality control ruins everythingThe oculus quest is the VR headset to get after the launch Oculus Link... not only can you play PC free, you can also play PC VR games like half life alyx on the quest - it even works with the USB cable out of the box! However poor quality control ruined my experience. Right out of the box I noticed a lot of glare. while "god rays" are expected due to the way the lenses work, what I was seeing was from the inside of the right lens being cloudy. The effect is like wearing glasses that you smeared your finger oil all over.Until QC can be improved, I cannot recommend the quest.
review_title: Poor quality control, one of the lens is cloudy causing glare

one_reviews_text: I have both a Vive, and a Vive Pro with an Nvidia 1080x graphics card.  This is better than that.  It looks better, it plays better, there are no cables, and it is VERY portable.  No perceptible god rays.  No perceptible screen door effect.  I do not notice the difference in refresh rate whatsoever.  Maybe it's there? but the experience is so vastly improved by the lack of cables and the fact that I can use this anywhere that I do not notice it.  I should note that I had an Oculus dev kit2 and a Samsung Gear VR, so I've been at this for awhile.  I know the difference between good and bad VR.  This is VERY good VR.  I paid $800 for my Vive, and over $3000 for the computer I run it on 2 years ago.  This miracle cost me $400.  I can't see why I'd need a 128G version.  Do yourself a favor if you like cool stuff that works awesome.  Love the controllers too.  I got one of those silicone covers for the headset and controllers too.  Good investment!  I use this for working out (Beat Sabre, Box VR, Thrill of the fight)  I have all of these games on Steam VR and they are much more enjoyable to play on the Quest.

This product shows free returns for the Amazon return policy. I guess I needed to read every tiny detail because they charged me back $124 as a restocking fee. obviously it does not cost them that much. I ask if they would just apply that charge to the occulus ghost but they would not cooperate. The hand devices were heavy for my small hands and or not easy to use, especially if you have a little bit of arthritis in your hands.
review_title: buyers beware of free return policy.

one_reviews_text: This is a different kind of review meant for people who could only choose between an Oculus or traditional (PS5, XBox). I had to choose between the two and I opted for the Oculus; it's a decision I regret painfully. It isn't that this is a bad system. We all know that the speed and graphics couldn't compete with the traditional model gaming, but I was willing to sacrifice that for a full-immersion experience. And, ironically, that's why I regret it. The Oculus is just "too much" for me in every way. It's too long to get up and running, it's too slow, but most of all, it's too immersive. I like my gaming experience to be fun and casual. I like to hit pause easily and grab a snack, look out the window, or check my phone. It gets exhausting to put on the headset, check the batteries, check your radius of play, adjust the headset, wait minutes to navigate and load your game, and then have to wonder what you're missing on the outside world. The first hour of having this was awesome. Since then, I just don't find it worth the time to play. My advice? Go with PS4, PS5 or the XBOX. It's just easier and more fun.

This is my first time using a VR, the Quest is VERY uncomfortable to wear on my face. It's a heavy device so I don't recommend playing on it for too long as it will leave red marks on your forehead and cheeks (honestly it feels like it tugs at my skin). That aside, the games on it are $10-30 bucks so if you don't plan on spending anymore after you get the VR Quest you're out of luck here unless you connect it to a free game on a computer. The setup on the computer took a while especially since it did not come with a USB-C cord;  low-grade ones will not work so don't even try.After buying an appropriate USB-C cord for the VR Quest, it finally connected to the computer so I could play online games. As for the console games, I played the demo games and all were fun especially BeatSaber which I ended up purchasing with my VR. The battery life lasts two hours at most and then it needs to be charged.  All in all, love the experience--I don't think it's worth $500 even as a novelty item---definitely not. The uncomfortability wearing it is huge for being on your face even for 5 minutes.4.5 stars for the experience. Would be 5 if it wasn't so uncomfortable to wear and expensive for what it's not worth. Will update later if I have anything else to add.::JUNE UPDATE:: The controllers become disconnected often on fullbattery. This has nothing to do with connectivity as I connect my Oculus to the bluetooth? (which I didn't even need to do before..) Sometimes I play and my hand just disappears on screen, or worse, both of them do. Strange since I didn't even own it for a year and I take very good care of this thing.
review_title: Doesn't come with a usb-c cord....unbearable to wear.

one_reviews_text: I've only been using it a few hours, so I might amend this later to give an updated review. However, it's a lot of fun, and I like it a lot. The price is right..The good:it is easy to setup and go. ( I had an initial problem with the left controller connecting, but unpair it and repair it worked fine after)you don't need a pc. just a android or apple phone..Good selection of games to use.Graphics are great.the headset is surprisingly comfortable, you get used to it. It's just a matter of getting the right adjustment.The neutral:Even though you're not tethered to a pc, You still need a fair amount of space to use this.  Most of the games recommend a 61/2 by 61/2 foot guardian space to safely play.  I'd would say based on a person's  height  that the space be at least a foot or more beyond a person's hands if they were to stretch their arms out, like making human letter T, in any direction.  A person 6'2" would need more space than me at 5'7" for safe game play.The bad..so far I haven't really run into huge negatives. that bother me a lot.Battery life is shorter than I would hope for, about 2 hours.Makes me wish I had a full blown star trek holodeck.I recommend this, totally work the purchase.

Original Quest would not charge either to a defective battery or cable. Requested replacement and Amazon shipped me a new set before I even returned the defective set. Bravo to Amazon.The Oculus Quest is unbelievable and one has to see it to believe it. You can’t believe the technology!Fabulous product and highly recommended!!!!Having had this product for 3 months, I am downgrading my rating from 5 stars to 1 star. I have just received my second replacement of the Oculus Quest. The Oculus Quest has suddenly stopped charging on my first 2 units. Secondly, virtually everyone who owns the Oculus can’t cast the image from the headset to your iPhone as it is supposed to do.To make matters worse, there support system is horrible and there’s no phone number available for one to speak to a human about a technical problem.My opinion is that Oculus Quest was prematurely released with multiple bugs in the system. It needed months of work by R & D before it was released. Wouldn’t recommend buying until Oculus gets their act together and eliminates the bugs and develop a functional support system, which includes a phone number so someone with a problem can speak to another person.
review_title: Don’t Buy Now- To many problems!!!!

one_reviews_text: When I first received my headset, it was everything I could've expected: good graphics, responsive, immersive, etc. But now that I've had it for a month or two, I'm no longer satisfied.I mainly bought my headset to play VRchat. In this game, I was looking forward to being able to experience all different types of avatars and people. However, I can see almost no avatars in this game, and the headset overall is very glitchy.I have experienced many different glitches while using my Oculus Quest. The first glitch I ever encountered was that while playing VRchat, the game would either freeze and send me to my home room (in-game) or would just close itself. Then, I started having the issue of a complete black screen. People in-game could still hear and see me, and I could still hear them. But all I could see was a black screen. My biggest glitch so far is currently happening right now. When I try to turn on my headset, it acts as if it is brand new, automatically putting me into the "First Steps" simulation. When I get through it, I am put into my home, where I can see the space around me, but I cannot see my home screen. I can see my menu bar at the bottom, but any screen I try to view simply isn't there. When I try to manually access VRchat or any other game from the Oculus app on my iPad, the whole game crashes in the headset and ultimately puts me back into my home space without my home screen. I would not recommend this headset to anyone and I fully regret buying it.
review_title: Good at first, but glitches increase with time.

one_reviews_text: If you're looking to get into VR (and you can look past the fact that Facebook owns Oculus), this is the headset to get. Being wire + PC free and still able to play really fun games is amazing. Beat Saber and other games are great workouts too!Pros:- Library is growing rapidly / Fun games- Most games are <= $25, All are $30 max- Game Refund policy- Developers listen and patch often- My 95 yr old Grandma thought it was cool- Guardian system- Sound is surprisingly good from headset- Easy to use the Store- Can play while you charge- FB is constantly updating and adding features like Oculus Link, hand tracking, etcCons:- 72 Hz refresh rate on lenses can make you sick on rail movement type games. Not as great as higher end sets obviously.- Casting drops often, even on 5Ghz- Facebook owns Oculus / What are they doing with the data?- Must use FB account to sign in for Social features (friends list, etc)- Foam facepad soaks up and holds sweat (get the VR facepad 3rd party accessory)
review_title: Headset to Get for VR Beginners

one_reviews_text: First, the Oculus Quest is great.  Being untethered is the best way to experience VR.I've only played PSVR for comparison, and the Oculus is a technically superior experience in every way.  The tracking and motion controllers are more accurate and better designed, and the Guardian system is fantastic.  The only problem is that the headset itself is not nearly as physically comfortable an experience.  It takes much fiddling to get the fit and feel right, and even then, it's not what it should be.I feel that when you pay this much for an item that is otherwise well-made, comfort shouldn't be such an issue that you end up buying additional accessories to jury-rig your headset.  They could have put more thought into the weight distribution, and it feels like they just phoned-in the strap design.  Additionally, you're going to get sweat and oils from your skin on the face mask, and while the material of the Oculus is nice, it just absorbs all that grodiness.So far, I've purchased silicone mask covers for easy cleaning and materials to make a counterweight for the back of the strap.  It has helped, but it's not ideal.  I may try one of the padded strap rigs down the road, but I don't really want to spend the money for more accessories that may or may not help.  If you want an affordable counterweight example, I bought a small pouch of diving shot and used velcro loops to secure it to the strap.
review_title: Five stars for function, three stars for comfort

one_reviews_text: I used to own an Oculus Rift (OG retail) and sold it for a few reasons:1) The screen door effect was awful2) Setting up all of the sensors each time I wanted to use it was a massive choreThe Quest somewhat solves the first one and completely solves the second one. The Quest has a much higher resolution, and "inside out" tracking, which means no external sensors. I've read in reviews that people had better results with the external sensors, I completely disagree. I have WAY better results tracking the headset and the controllers with the "inside out" tracking on the Quest.A complaint I heard is that the Quest is heavy, I don't think it is at all. Another complaint is the loss of headphones using speakers instead, but I prefer this because if something happens in the "real world" (doorbell, etc) I'm not unresponsive and lost in the game.The new hand tracking (in beta) absolutely blew my mind, it's so cool and has a ton of potential for future games once it's refined.Being able to use the Quest as both standalone and as a Rift using the Link makes it more versatile. I've noticed that I need to be plugged into a USB 3.1 "Gen 2" port in order for the signal to stay reliable. The standard USB 3.0 (aka 3.1 gen 1) ports seem to cut out or have trouble connecting.To me the Quest is a massive leap forward, but there's still the nagging issue of putting a 1440p screen, a low resolution by modern standards, a millimeter from your eyeball. It does not have the razor sharp precision we're getting used to with 4K screens at a reasonable difference. Until we can get 4K or better yet 8K per eyeball, VR is not able to replicate the pixel fidelity of a console/PC game. That is a long way away, but the Quest proves innovation in other important areas are making the architecture of this technical far more accessible.

This works fine I guess, it's great that they can be used wirelessly or wired like a more traditional HMD. The question I have is more about the future of VR as a whole. The games for this thing are actually pretty terrible, so many stupid games where you stand in place and shoot things, or maybe you're on rails. The medium feels strangled by people refusing to accept any game that isn't 1st person when having games playable in 3D could be promising and make for a larger variety. The battery life hasn't been an issue since I usually get bored of the "experiences" long before they have time to run out. The interface is a bit annoying to navigate and it just feels like there's very little to do on it right now. VR as a whole is still hoping you'll be amazed by the ability to control things rather than having control just be part of what makes the game amazing. Hopefully in the future there will be cheaper headsets with less restrictions on what uses they have.
review_title: Wonder how well this technology will do.

one_reviews_text: Packaging :High quality. Everything is neat and pretty. Sounds funny, but this is the best nylon wrapping I have seen in my life.You feel this is a premium product when you unbox it.Usage and comfort:This is actually a lot of fun, the tracking is perfect, and some games are really fun. I think this is the first VR device that isn't a niche product - VR for the mass.The real issue with it is, as you can expect, the weight.  This thing is heavy and will hurt your face.  Sometimes you play with the straps and get to a sweet spot.. but mostly it will not be comfortable.  I still play, but I get really red marks on my face afterwards.Sound:Not as bad as people say, absolutely playable. But...one you try it with earphones , that's a one way ticket.Screen:Well.. although this is a high res OLED screen(s), this resolution is just not enough.  It's  OK and you will still have fun, and it will be immersive.. but the resolution is just not high enough at this stage.  It's all pixels (doesn't matter if you use Link or not - the resolution isn't there). You get used to it, but don't expect anything nearly close to what you see on a computer screen - maybe in 3-5 years or so.What I am bothered with is the significant amount of users with Dead Pixels out of the box.  Yes, I have them too.  Around 3 green pixels which never change.  Luckily they are not in the center so I kinda got used to ignore them.  Just a thing to keep in mind if you are a pixel peeper. Get it in a place which will let you replace it if you do get dead pixels.  BTW, google  it, there are a lot of users with the same issue.Prices:Games are generally too expensive for what you get.  No way around it.  The price of a simple VR game is usally around $30. You do get an option to ask for a full refund if haven't played it for more than 2 hours.I'm not sure I can recommend games here as Amazon might not approve this review if I do so..I won't.Conclusion:Really cool device - totally fun.Just be sure to know that you might get dead pixels , the resolution is much lower than what you would expect form a 2020 gaming device, and it is very front heavy.Are there any wireless alternatives to the Quest?  Not at this time.

Love it!Pro'sFairly easy set up.High Fun FactorWow!Everything from packaging to set up to buying and installing apps is very smooth.Battery has long life.The Guardian (holo-deck like grid that you set up to be your boundary is super cool to set up and works great!)Con'sHeadset isn't flush on my face (big cheekbones) so I have to crank it tight to get a snug fit. (no light leaking in)Head gets sore after about an hour of use. (I think this is the norm for all VR headsets)I've been waiting several years to buy a VR set ever since they announced them. I think this is the one to make it big. The no cords, free to walk around is awesome and a game changer.

I purchased this device in July and spent a month trying to get it working, buying every suggested cable and card. I was able to get it working, using advice from other users because the tech support was over run and seemed to be giving marginally useful advice from a pre-set script.Following instructions, I bought the 80 dollar official cable that didn't work, and bought a special card to work with the cable that didn't work, and then bought another cable and some adapters and a splitter, I ended up returning all of that crap and buying a simple Anker USB 3.0, you'll see it referenced in other reviews I'm sure.Now with a working VR kit, I play for a month and all is fine. Except now Facebook has decided it wants to rebrand the Oculus name and take ownership, with a lot of software updates and drivers on desktop and inside the VR headset, all pointing you in the direction of logging in to and then using Facebook on VR. Which is fine and dandy, if it worked at all. Trying to play games leads to random disconnects from the computer, random lockups and freezes in the apps. Lots of other Oculus Quest users reporting similar issues, and no fixes.If you think this is a good deal, just be careful. If it gives you the slightest issue, don't trust the process, get your money back  otherwise you'll be trying to get technical service up to and beyond the time you can return it, and that suits Amazon just fine.
review_title: Beware: Oculus or Facebook will break it with an update in a month so you can't play it or return it

one_reviews_text: This headset is an amazing platform. Its inside out tracking works very well and the image quality is high. I love that you can choose to see the real world if you want and the room scale guardian makes me feel safe to not worry about my surroundings. And I love that it will remember your play area between uses. This is the first vr headset I have tried that makes me believe the platform is viable. And it accommodates my large IPD.The cons:- the headset is new so its library of apps is small- many of the apps are the same as other platform's just with bigger price tags- it's not yet compatible with the go library (but oculus claims it will)- its heavier then the go but the extra features make it worth it- there is no brightness adjustment so expect the rays of god. If you are technologically inclined you can side load an app to turn on blue light filtering which will help- the battery is a little small but I get why. The headset does not need more weight. Just plug in when using stationary apps

This is my first VR headset, and frankly, it’s my first meaningful VR experience. I really like it overall. I’m impressed with the amount of content available and was pleased to learn that many of the Oculus entertainment apps (Netflix, Venues, Sling, etc.) are available for the Quest. The headset is comfortable overall, but it needs to be positioned pretty precisely or the images are a tad blurry.I think there’s definitely some room for improvement on battery life and the quality / clarity of the screen. I understand that they couldn’t necessarily offer top-of-the-line hardware at this price point, but I expected a little better in both regards. They do provide a very long power cord, but being tethered to a power cord defeats the purpose of a cordless headset.
review_title: Very Cool, but Room for Improvement

one_reviews_text: We got this because my son really wanted Beat Saber.  He loves video games and he can be plenty physically active if we're doing something he likes, but he's not into playing sports.  I wanted him to get more exercise.  He now plays Beat Saber pretty much every day.  He gets a great workout and always has to shower after 'cause he gets so sweaty!  He's told me about so many things in his health and mental state that have improved since he began exercising daily with this game.  It's really amazing.  As far as the system itself, it is very impressive.  So simple to use and setup.  He can take it anywhere, setup his perimeters, and begin playing right away.  The only downside is the face cover gets really saturated with sweat if you're playing an active game.  We ended up buying a couple extra covers that are probably vinyl and don't absorb sweat. Those were a good addition.  All the games are remarkably small compared to what I was expecting.  The 64 GB size has been plenty.
review_title: Excellent for fun and burning calories!

one_reviews_text: I'm surprised how much I actually like this VR headset!I bought this primarily for gaming and was a little hesitant because at the time of purchase there weren't that many titles that appealed to me (i like FPS type games), and this made the price seem high just to play some VR games (been to several VR game centers in Tokyo so love VR).  However, after getting the headset i realized, OMG, there is much more to the headset than just gaming!  Regarding the limited number of appealing titles, quite a few new games are added frequently.WHAT I LIKEMany Amazon Prime shows and movies can be watched (not all tho), as well as YouTube and Netflix (if you have a subscription).  What's especially cool about watching movies with the headset is it's like being in a large, plush movie theater with a huge screen in front of you!  You look around and see a dimly lit theater, but, once the movie gets underway, the virtual room goes dark with just a large screen in front of you.With the ability to orient the view, I can lay on the sofa or in bed and watch movies or TV programs.  This means watching movies and TV programs is no longer limited to which room the TV is located in!I'm enjoying the Boxing VR workout sessions.  There are a variety of workouts to chose from, and I can do them anytime in the comfort and privacy of my own home.  For the most part, I like the accompanying music selections and the different gym types add the experience.  The workout sessions do give me quite a workout!I didn't expect to have my own virtual home whenever I'm wearing the headset, and the homes are quite impressive.  Some of the views are Sooo impressive and/or relaxing, I feel like getting a beverage, sitting back and just enjoying the view!My fav game so far is Pistol Whip.  It's like being John Wick!  This is an exciting, fast-paced game, which is a workout in itself!You can have the best of 2 worlds; Quest and Rift.  The Quest is an untethered device with the option to tether and have access to Rift games.Since the headset is self-contained and not tethered to a PC, it can be taken anywhere you go for gaming, TV, movies, workouts, etc.WHAT I DON'T LIKEThe headset has some weight to it, so after a while you start to feel the weight.  I've read Facebook will produce in the future a lighter weight headset.The games aren't cheap!  I purchased a couple of titles "right off the bat", and I regretted it.  I recommend before purchasing a game, checkout the reviews and watch previews on YouTube to have a good idea if it's something you'll enjoy.
review_title: Like it more than I thought I would  . .

one_reviews_text: I had never peeked inside a VR headset before buying this sight unseen.  I had read a lot of negative reviews of VR over the years, so I wasn't expecting much.  This probably contributed to my "holy s***" reaction to my first 5 minutes going through the First Steps tutorial.  The Quest VR is really a new kind of human experience.  I was truly blown away by home convincing the VR effect is.Now that I've had about 10 days with it, I thought I'd write a review.  The "omfg, wow" factor has worn off a little bit, but this is still a remarkable technology that really does transport you into a different realm for a short time.  I have picked it up every day I've had it, and so has everyone else in my family.There are some imperfections.  There is sometimes some glare in the lenses, or other optical deficiencies that detract from the experience.  But for the most part, it is an amazing effect.  "Running around" by using the controllers makes me motion sick in less than a minute.  I can't do that, so that limits the things I'm able to do a little bit.  But there's still plenty to do that feels very comfortable.  The Beat Saber game is a nice meditation.  The "Thrill of the Fight" game is a surprisingly good workout that has me huffing and puffing in no time.  There isn't a huge library of games, but there's enough good quality stuff right now to tide me over until the library expands, which I'm sure it will.Is it worth $400?  I would say it is.  There's more tech here than in a quality mobile phone that costs $400 and up.  It's a worthy addition as a "game console" in the same price range.If you've been waiting for VR to "make sense" in terms of price and performance and experience, the time is now.
review_title: It's not perfect, but 4 stars doesn't seem right either

one_reviews_text: Most reviews that have anything bad to say about the Quest say that it's not as good as HTC or Rift. Well, I say the Quest is amazing and they should shut their rich mouths. Not everyone can afford a massive gaming rig to run those headsets. The Quest has given me the opportunity to experience VR, which is something I've dreamed of doing since I was 5 (and I'm old)! The video quality is adequate, the sound is incredible, and the immersion is a religious experience.
