This was my first experience with a VR device and I am absolutely blown away by the way you feel like you have left the planet and are in a totally new reality. I had no idea how truly immersive it can be.Just get one, you won’t be disappointed.
It's a mind blowing experience and that's all I could really say !! I dispise cables and wires and that's add another reason why I love quest so much.

This is my first virtual reality headset and I was overall impressed with the quality of the games and system.  Some games have bugs but that is expected during the initial version. Definitely recommend getting one if you have wanted to play VR without having to break the bank.

Simply AMAZING! Beat Saber is so much fun with no cables. Best option for social VR by far...invite friends and cast to the TV and have a blast. Plus...with the Link option you can be in rift mode.I can't recommend this enough...5 stars...no it deserves way more than 5 out of 5!!!Only thing...get a aftermarket facial interface as you will sweat in the original. Oh and the Party Link cable never worked for me, but a cheap Gizzu did.

Just amazing! Imersive experiences, great games. Watch movies in what looks like a movie theater. The hardware is way above it's time. A true VR experience without the high end computer and sensors all around your house.
review_title: The next great thing in technology

one_reviews_text: Buy tons from Amazon regularly, but rarely comment, but I have to say this is an amazing product, even my 2 years and 5 years can enjoy technology and watch 360 video in Youtube, so we got some nice family time, thanks to this standalone system without cable.

Worth it! I've had so much fun playing games. I bought hand weights to play beat saber. It makes it for a great workout! I love being able to go different places and just flip it on and let me friends play. I didn't have to buy an expensive computer. I am looking forward to playing this for a long time!

I was surprised by what a highly portable VR device was capable of doing. This is so awesome that everyone who I've let experience it is buying one! Oculus is adding more and more content every week it seems. My mind was just blown away! If you wanna really have some action packed moments on the quest, I suggest:#1 - RoboRecall#2 - Creed#3 - Drop Dead (I love killing zombies!)

The great thing about the Oculus Quest is the immersion you feel right off the bat. Younger kids like 12 and below are harder to teach and pick up on what to do. I have wasted much time trying to get them to even get going with Beat Saber, so save your time and tell them it for kids 14 and up. Otherwise it has been a very positive experience and a great workout. Can’t wait for more great games.
review_title: Amazing gaming platform with huge potential!

one_reviews_text: It's awesome! No wires makes it super easy to get very immersed. Just a few clicks and I can share my screen to Chromecast, and have my family join in on the fun.

My 11 year old boy loves this. I tried it out, AWESOME. A bit pricey and not many games but it’s early in its infancy. So much better than those cheap one that use your phone. Best thing is that you don’t have wires, have to connect to a computer etc. Bought the travel case and my son can bring anywhere there is internet. Quality!!!
Wow! This blew me away. I’m a generation “X” Mom and this tech is bad a**!Only down side, I can’t pay for games using apple gift cards. Have to use a credit card.
review_title: The second you put it on- mind blown

one_reviews_text: This is an awesome headgear! It is waay more advanced than a 3D, it's actually around a 6D where you can actually feel fully immersed in the experiences. This is true and absolute fun for the entire family!
review_title: In Another World Where You Can Almost Feel and Touch

one_reviews_text: At $399 the Oculus quest has brought an AMAZING VR experience... My biggest worries getting into such a cheap VR headset was "What if things are blurry or grainy?", or "What if it the sensors don't pick up anything because, maybe it's made cheap?". Putting on and handling the quest blew me away. Visually it's impressive,  the games and apps all work great, and I've been going at beat saber since I got the thing! I highly recommend this product, and am very happy with all it has to offer.

Long story short if you are thinking of getting into a Oculus. Go for this, cheapest on the market and for paying more then the Oculus Go you get so many more worth while upgrades. Like the games you can get and the second controller for Saber beats. This console has been in my house for 3 months and a day hasn't gone by without it being played.
review_title: If you were thinking about it do it.

one_reviews_text: I am giving this 5 stars even though i received a defective product. The headset i received would not work under any circumstances for more than a few minutes at a time. Amazon offers full refund but no replacement and the price has been raised considerably since i first purchased mine. Oculus,however, is sending me a new one once they receive the defective one. The sort time i was able to play was truly magical and i cant wait to get the replacement.

This vr headset is amazing it is my first one and I'm happy that I waited. There are some down sides to the item but not that bad. For example the game store for it does not have a big verity of games but it will still be updating so it isn't something to dwell on. It can only play for about 2 hours and charge for 2 hours which is a bummer but it helps with breaks. I believe it is worth the money because you don't have to worry about a super computer and the cables on your back. All in all 10/10 would recommend
review_title: Pros and pros a tiny bit of cons

one_reviews_text: Love my Quest. Just wish it had more card games.They need to add uno, black jack, and especially  spades. They have 2 games dedicated to freakin poker. Poker sucks lol its not for everyone.

VR is finally here! I was a little skeptical of a stand-alone headset (i.e. no computer with crazy GPU needed), but I ordered one on a whim under the presupposition that I could just send it back if it was lame. I will not be sending it back. The apps / experiences are still somewhat limited, but there is certainly enough to stay entertained, and the future is bright.
review_title: VR is no longer just for nerds...

one_reviews_text: This thing is hot, uncomfortable, front heavy, low res, really low battery life, can see out of the nose area and the advertised 58 to 72 ipd is actually 59 to 71(I am a 58). I had it on for 30 minutes and could tell it was going back. I also have a rift s that is going back also because it has fixed lenses and out of my ipd range so everything is blurry, but besides that it is everything this is not. If you are ok with the ipd range and have a good computer get the rift S.

I brought this for my sons 7th birthday & it’s fantastic.  Very easy to setup on your phone and the graphics are amazing, I was pleasantly surprised & not Being wired to a pc makes it a perfect piece of kit for a kid to use.  Defiant impressed so far.

My daughter is addicted to beat saber. So far she has cracked one of the rings on the controller from dropping it, nothing a little electric tape couldn't fix. I don't like not being able to have multiple accounts, but I got it for her so it's hers anyway. Some games have options for other players. Make sure you have room to play, it can be glitchy if you try an play the wrong kind of game in to small of a guardian area. Casting to a chromecast is the best thing ever, so others can watch.

I love this the graphics are great for a all in one virtual reality headset if you do already have a high powered pc the I recommend the htc vive but if you don’t have a high power pc this is the best  alternative
was a little glitchy when I first tried it but I'm guessing thats how it is the first use but after it updated it works great
Twelve year old loves this. So much fun!
This is a lot of fun both kids and adults.  Very immersive.  Lots of content for everyone to enjoy.  An added bonus is that the right games serve as a great workout too!
review_title: Lots of fun for everyone who tries it

one_reviews_text: This VR set up is so awesome it’s very nice not having to have an expensive computer and cables everywhere sure the graphics could be a little bit sharper but that is only a matter of time it’s a big hit when I have friends and family come over and they try Richies plank challenge LOL we love this machine and definitely recommend it to others

Perfect for a quarantine pandemic. Stuck at home? Well put the head set on and experience traveling to new places meeting people threw virtual reality chatting watch movies brows the inter webs. I can’t even begin to explain how much I love this system.

I love it. A lot. I do hours and hours of fitness apps a week. I am a jedi. I play to the rhythm of music. I meet new people and play paintball. I enter large spaces and movie theaters and watch movies together. I am transported to every universe that has been out of our reach until now.This is the future.
review_title: This is the first real attempt at a device for a wider audience.

one_reviews_text: No parental controls. Free access to web browsing and adult games. Completely inappropriate, returning it right away.
Love it.  Its not the worlds best but for me it offers best of both worlds.  Pc and portable.  Game selections lack compared to pc. But i hope with time it will grow.

I've had a Rift for a few years now and have never enjoyed VR more than I have with the Quest.  It is amazing to no longer be attached to a PC.  The freedom to move around and play in spaces that you never could before is awesome.  This is the device that brings VR to the masses.
My son is 12. I purchased the Oculus Quest for him for Christmas and he absolutely loves it. I would definitely recommend. Easy to set up with awesome graphics!!!!

My 13 year old son absolutely loves this! Easy to set up and easy to use.  I set up the app on my phone to buy games,  but you can also see what he sees and cast it to the tv. It's very entertaining watching him play with it.

Awesome VR system, with a great library of games  If you are thinking about getting into VR, this is the system. No Computer.No fumbly set up. A great support team. A reasonable price point. Grab one and have fun!- welcome to the future of Virtual Reality
All around this headset is good... except for game selection. Games run really well and headset is great for travel but the cameras struggle in the black/white guardian cams
review_title: Good but cameras glitch in the guardian camera.

one_reviews_text: This is my 13 yo son's favorite gift. Gets him up and moving. He loves the graphics, that it is wireless.  Hand tracking is great. He says weight distribution is good.
It's a beautiful unit but overpriced for the limited games and constant issues. Money wasted.
It's all that and a bag of chips (PERIOD!)Scrap together $399, sell some soda/pop bottles, or tear the couch/sofa apart and buy one of these. Freak the crap out of your parents!!!

The Oculus Quest would be my first VR headset and I am so glad I bought it. The day I bought it the Oculus Link arrived and now you can use it to play PCVR games if your PC is up to it. Setting it up was easy since it guides you step-by-step on how to do it, and the experience is so fun. I recommend it to be able to escape reality from time to time :)

Not a gamer really, but VR viewing has seriously obsoleted regular TV/computer screen viewing for me.  My viewing preference now demands this higher level of immersion. Headset weight is an inconvenience that I put up with in exchange for my eyes finally being free to look around.
review_title: Surprised by how much I use it

one_reviews_text: Only 4 months and we have issues with the software with no phone# to call for help. Submitted online for issues with oculus with no response. My son just purchased a game before it gave an error message and hasn’t been able to play. Very disappointing for what you pay.

I really like how I can leave it lying around and put it on for a few quick minutes of gaming whenever I have just a bit of time to kill. It's like my phone - it's a convenient way to burn a few minutes and easy to put down when I get interrupted.
Awesome experience.  Add the HTC vive headset and it's perfect.  Added a battery pack, too.  Hours of funj.

Es realmente excelente, y si bien falta que todos estos dispositivos mejoren su resolución creo que es un hermoso casco de VR. La inmersión es total, el catálogo de juegos también.Lo que veo como puntos negativos son la duración de la batería y la necesidad de comprar el cable Oculus Link aparte a USD 80 para jugar juegos de PC.
The oculus quest was great but only for a month If you dont have a group of friends it gets boring doing the same thing by your self
review_title: This is a great item but keep in mind it isn’t as good it you have a group of friends

one_reviews_text: It’s been an amazing headset super fun but About a week ago it just stopped working I turn it on and it doesn’t recognize why I am logged me out of my account and it doesn’t let me play any of the games I’ve bought kind of sucks I’m trying to fix it but it’s a pretty good headset just really upset about this I paid $400 there shouldn’t be an issue

It’s great in all and I was very surprised how well the tracking works, but the speakers are not the best, I guess that doesn’t matter, the gameplay is pretty good I seen a few glitches here and there, like how sometimes games will go completely black and you’ll have to restart, was hoping this would be fixed considering that this problem was on the go as well. Also it will not let you add prepaid cards as a payment method, all the cards I’ve tried to add it would never let me.
Kids still love this thing !!!!!!

The item itself is great, the software and updates are amazing, not being able to use some of the applications unless you have a FB account is what made me deduct a star. I don't want a FB account and I shouldn't be punished for my choice.
Love it. And especially with the oculus link cable and functionality, there's no better option when it comes to value and pure VR experience.

Great family fun and great for exercising and losing weight. The one negative is casting to the TV....the sound and video latency is not good. If They could correct this problem....it would be perfect.
The gaming is incredible.  Until the screen quits. Second problem since Christmas.  I give up this thing is just not worth it.
My 12 year old received this for Christmas and the only time he put it down is when he is in school. It also fun for family game nights.

For 400 bucks it is an amazing gadget to keep in your bachelor pad if you make more than $100k. A single trip to VR world costs $40 + tax. I bought the archery game which was awesome. Tons of other free or affordable games.
The most fun I've had in a while.  The past few days I was emotionally down but with this I've been insanely happy with all the fun
I was hesitant to buy but I couldn’t be happier, it’s a pretty good workout, the wander app is awesome, I love all of it.  I’ve been using it for about two weeks and I’m still amazed by it.

I absolutely love my Oculus go and my Oculus quest I still use my Oculus go for movies I do play games on my Oculus quest I love it I am requesting a return and a an exchange because the right ear sound has a little vibration in it that can cause irritation when playing on it but as a whole it's just fantastic to him and his new things become available and ways to do things I think it's just a fabulous product
review_title: Just grab it and enjoy it make sure you got room

one_reviews_text: I was reading reviews about people needing a newer smartphone but my uncle's iPhone 4 ran it smoothly with success, perhaps they fixed that issue. With that aside, this device is a delight. My uncle had gotten one and let me try it, and I decided I needed one after using his. No matter what age you are, the vr is fun for everyone. My seventy year old grandparents had a blast on this thing, and the younger kiddos loved it!

It only worked good  for 24 hours. After that three dots don’t let me do anything. I tried everything possible, did factory resetting and reboot it couple times. Also downloaded the app again on my phone. But nothing seems like working. I also emailed quest support about help, including serial number, but no response from them yet. I probably gonna wait couple more days for response before I return it.
review_title: Three dots don’t let me do anything

one_reviews_text: Working great. A pain to connect to pc but doable. Using virtual desktop to play bone works on steam vr.

The product is great. I see a lot of potential but there aren't enough apps available yet. I can do a lot more on my gear vr. I don't always want to play games. The entertainment side is a little lacking. I haven't touch my quest in awhile some of the games are too expensive.
Absolutely wonderful! Great gift and very fun for all ages! Love that its completely wireless and games are within good price ranges.

This is one of the coolest things I’ve ever bought for myself, after saving up money from work. It has great graphics, it’s comfortable, it has a spacer for people (like me) with glasses, and best of all, you can set it up and start playing in minutes! Would recommend.
Give me a headache so I don’t play it much!
The freedom that the wireless feature allows provides play spaces even outside. The games available make this a very good choice. Beat Saber, Elven Assassin and a few excellent room puzzle games.
Everything came in great packaging.  My son LOVES this game!  He  bought it himself and plays it a lot.  It's REALLY, really cool!  Fast shipping.
This VR is awesome! Games galore, performance second to none, and very well made device! I highly recommend buying one of these.
awesome product to get us closer to more affordable vr
review_title: son uses it almost every day

one_reviews_text: This is aMaZiNgI had the cv1 and it much better-using link or without.Pros:FunGreat screen qualityFunTouch controllerfUnWirelessDid i mention fun yet?Cons:Sound qualityBattle lifeYou can't charge the controllers as you charge the questSum up:5/5 reality is here to define!!
review_title: The best vr headset out there by far

one_reviews_text: Beat VR headset to date! No wires, pretty good battery life and a pretty descent library and growing. If you’ve never experienced VR before, this will blow you away. If you’ve used VR before, this is the headset you’ve been waiting for. The 64GB version is plenty unless you want to buy every single game/experience.

Absolutely blown away by the oculus quest. Picture is great. Fits just fine. The price for what this is in my opinion is a complete steal. Would buy again. I planned to buy another soon. Con: and only reason not 5 stars. It wants to disconnect to wifi randomly. Not all the time I should add. Hopefully since I've only had this few day only. That its fixes its self with upcoming updates...
review_title: absolutely amazing must at least experience

one_reviews_text: Tetherless with 6 degrees of freedom provides a rich VR experience.  Beat Saber and Table Tennis are great games for immersion into the VR space.  I can definitely recommend this product.
The most amazing VR glasses  IN THE WORLD. The rate quality / price. I am very happy!

I say it is very good for the price the only thing that i have a problem with is that if you have the headset on for a while longer than 1 hour it can irritate your skin and make a bit of a rash on your skin but not that bad for the fun you will have.

This person might be shipping refurbs, but the one I got was pristine. Works great, is a ton of fun. Play it more than my consoles. I have nothing negative to say about the seller, mine was still shrink wrapped. Maybe I got lucky. Mine was listed as like new and that's what I got. It might be a gamble but I came out ahead.
I bought this in June for $400 and now the 64GB Quest 2 is $300 in September. Do not buy this. Go buy Quest 2.

As a Previous Go owner:Resolution is superb, games have better graphics. With Oculus link, you can play rift games. Screen-door effect lower than go but still a little visible. Controllers have good feature set.Strap is not comfy as go. Weight balance is not centered so you feel pressure around your cheeks. Controllers feels not sturdy and have trigger noise.Still better than go and mk2 and happy woth it.
The build quality and screen resolution is amazing. Th screen door effect in hardly noticeable and the launch content is pretty great with several demos and free games to try.
review_title: Amazing Experience for anyone new or veteran to VR

one_reviews_text: You feel like you are in all of the places you visit but be careful playing the games b/c I fell over the coffee table and the tv hit me in the head lol.  I wish the battery life would be longer though.
review_title: Very fun but be cautious of your surroundings!!!

one_reviews_text: So much fun!!!Needs to be put on for a few hours to achieve comfort and appreciate the VR experience!No real complaints here, just having a blast using it!
Really can’t wrong buying this. It’s a whole new experience and the kids love it.
Easy to use, very high quality, no need for the Rift S as this packs high quality/speed/memory and portability.

I bought the Oculus Quest thinking it would be a fun toy for me and my family to play with. For the first couple weeks it was, but then I lost use and wished I had time to return it. I think it might be something I can use later in my life and I might regain a use for it, but right now . I partly want my money back.
review_title: Bought it for entertainment, Then lost intrest

one_reviews_text: the only 2 issues i have with this is the battery and the MAJOR lack of content for this device.... no joke it's lacking on games...... at best you will only find like 2-3 good games out of like 20ish games available for this
I love this! I’m now addicted to Beat Saber. The whole idea of VR is so cool. Buy one - they’re fun!

I bought this thinking there would be lots of games.Some of the games are great but the games I wanted to play are rift games. In order to play rift games you need a really good gaming computer plus you have to buy a chord to make it work.Hopefully they will come out with more
review_title: Nice but not what you think!!!

one_reviews_text: This VR headset is awesome. It comes with great games. The oculus store has a wide range of games8 and apps to choose from.
review_title: Headset is outstanding and fit is great

one_reviews_text: I used the more tempered version of certain games, but nothing could prepare me for the motion sickness I’d feel. It’s too bad, I really really wanted to love this
review_title: Loved it, but I have serious motion sickness

one_reviews_text: I bought this to use with VZFit for cycling.  It’s a lot of fun but if you get dizzy easily it’s probably not for you.  My husband can only use it sitting down but the kids love the games on it.
Really like vr but it will give you motion sickness. Grandkids fight over who gets to use it at grandmas house

Since the developers has decided to add a feature that allows users to use the headset on PC (Oculus Link), i just had to give this thing a better review.Probably the most notable downside is the weight of the headset on head, and might be quite uncomfortable for someone. And perhaps the prices of all games on Oculus Store.

Drops wifi connection frequently, limited to the oculus store unless you sideload.  Additional weight makes prolonged play uncomfortable.  Otherwise pretty good.  If you dont have a good computer it's a good alternative option, but the oculus rift is better in my opinion if your computer can handle it
MY KIDS LOVED THIS!!!! I was worried because it was way cheaper than others I seen of this on line but it was legit and awesome!!!
review_title: SUPER DUPER!!!!! My kids loved it and I was so amazed!

one_reviews_text: I am blown away with the Quest, no wires is amazing, I can take it anywhere and move however I like without worrying about tripping or getting tangled up. The games are enjoyable with Beat Saber being my favorite. One only real inconvenience with it is that it’s front heavy (which was expected) I found just tapping something to the back to help counter balance it helps so much.

Coming from PSVR, this device feels like 100 times better, I don't even know how to describe the experience, you have to try it yourself!!!Also since you are allowed to move freely, the motion sickness gets much lighter.I would definitely recommend this to anyone!

I enjoyed every part of it from the unboxing experience all the way to how easy it was to set up!I’m in love with the insight tracking and the fact that there are no wires! But that’s not all, you can hook it up to a pc to play rift games on the quest!I mean, how cool is that! It’s literally the Nintendo switch of VR! I am very excited to see where this platform goes and how it innovates the VR community to make headsets like this.
review_title: One of the best VR headsets for the price!

one_reviews_text: Lots of fun for adults too! Feels like you’re actually in another room or realm
WILL NOT WORK!
We g G ad this for 2 weeks & it just stopped working. Vendor didn’t respond to emails. Thank goodness for Amazon or we would have been out a lot of money

I am having a blast using the oculus. My only complaint with it is if someone turns on a light while I’m using it, the sensors go out of wack. It turned off on me when that happened.  Otherwise I love it.
The Oculus is proving to be a favorite with my grandsons...the technology is amazing.  I may have to get a set of my own!

Amazing response and very high quality. I thought the fabric was a little rough on the face pad after about an hour of usage, but bought a rubber cover which also protected that pad from sweat. It's so nice being hands free. Also with the announcement of the Oculus Link, it now makes the Rift S obsolete.
review_title: The best VR headset for your money.

one_reviews_text: As a new comer to VR, this is quite nice.  Easy to use and well thought out.  The image lacks a bit, but given the price, no complaint.

AMAZING! I have tried using other VR headsets before but always ended up feeling nauseous. I didn’t feel dizzy at all after using for about 20-30 min. It is such a cool experience that has so many possibilities.
The kid says it’s totally awesome. Way better then the PlayStation VR. Better graphics. No wires. He’s thrilled.

Going from 0 to immersive gaming in seconds would be impressive even if we weren't talking about VR, but the ease with which the Quest teleports you into another world is a real watershed moment in this growing segment of gaming. The library of games is large and growing. Beat Saber, Moss and The Exorcist are my standouts so, but there's a lot more I haven't got to yet that I want to.
review_title: The Quest is a full fat VR system that goes toe to toe with much more expensive options.

one_reviews_text: This has been so invaluable in my quarantine! I can literally escape to another world without leaving my house AND no wires!! I can see how people would get motion sickness, but not me.
My son absolutely loves this VR. He loves the fact that he can play with the cable plugged in. My only dislike is the price of the games. You don’t get many free games to try either.
Love almost everything about it. Easy to play games, easy to set up and stream. The head strap doesn't vary in size enough for my family.
I absolutely love love it it’s amazing the only thing that’s a problem now is that there is a screen door effect around the corners and the sound a little won key when the battery is low
Definitely not lacking any fun! Great if you want to be alone and in your own little world to watch Netflix, etc.

This is one of the most incredible experiences I have ever had. So amazed at how dynamically your movements are tracked and how immersive this is. I truly felt like I was in another world. Yes, it is expensive, but it is genuinely worth the money. So amazing.

Love the quest, works amazing haven’t had a problem yet. It came installed with a few demos and they were great to play. If you’re considering buying an oculus quest you most certainly should, I love mine. What’s really fun is to cast your screen to a phone or chrome cast enabled tv and let everyone around see what youre seeing. Great product, great user experience, easy to set up.
Good device, for price point OK. My first time with VR so no comparisons.Requires a smartphone for setup only, basically no reason.

Omg I can’t say enough about this. Our whole family plays this and it is just so cool. I love the games that came with this and even cancelled my previous order from somewhere else because this was such a good deal.
It’s super fun to play games and watch movies on! It does give me a headache after too long but my husband doesn’t get headaches from it.

Such an amazing device.  Am not a gamer, had difficulty learning how to work a gamepad.  This device is easy, intuitive to use, and really fun.  Total immersion.  Started exercising again with BoxVR and more recently Beat Saber both available to purchase through the Oculus store.  Just total fun!
package arrived when I was told it would - it was important b/c it was a birthday gift for my 10 year old nephew who really was hoping he would get it -he was very happy to receive it.

First real VR gear.  I love the freedom to move ( no cords ).  The foam eyepiece does press into my forehead hard enough to leave a red mark... I am in the market for a softer replacement piece like they make for the Rift and others.  The VR experience is awesome... recommend it to everyone!
The best VR you can experience if you don’t have a gaming PC, hands down. If you’re interested in VR, THIS is what you need to buy.
Amazing! I'm not really a gamer, just a casual PS 3 player, but the Quest blows me away. It can only get better as more software is developed. Verry cool machine!
I love this thing its very fun and even tho u gotta pay for most games it is still worth it. Very fun an great that u can play co op an multi-player an play anywhere any room.
review_title: Great way to pass time without being lazy

one_reviews_text: Works great and is an awesome piece of equipment. It kind of sucks that you have to spend a lot of money afterwards but I still love it.
This thing is so fun!  If you're getting a VR set I would highly suggest this one.  Ours did come with a scratch on the lens which is sad but it still seems to work fine!
Bought for the entire family and we have had a great time.  Some of the games are also a great workout!
Good quality video and incredible immersed VR experience.
It's pretty dang amazeballs, got it for my sister.
review_title: That this is now obsolete :) Get the Quest 2!

one_reviews_text: This is an amazing all in one vr headset the draw back is the controllers use AA batteries and the headset is only good for about 2 hours on one charge but you can play with the headset plugged in and the batterys in the controllers can last several days or weeks depending on usage. You can either buy bulk batteries or rechargeable ones for the controllers at any store. Totally worth every penny spent
review_title: Amazing all in one vr headset

one_reviews_text: Amazing. This really is the next step in vr. The difference between wired and wireless is night and day along with the fact that it runs as smooth as a pc headset.

Bought this one after we had bought the Oculus Rift, but realized we didn't have a gaming computer to run it.  This All-in-One works great, without the need for a gaming computer.  My son LOVES it.  Downloading games to it is very simple.  Set up is simple.  Overall great product!
This is the pinnacle of VR gaming. The oculus quest is beyond awesome, a must have for any gamer!
review_title: The Best VR Gaming System Period

one_reviews_text: I himed and hawed about purchasing this because it is a bit pricey- but seriously you will NOT be disappointed.  It's amazing and our whole family loves this
All good best buy i did, specially if you want to do some exercises and gaming it helps a lot

Much better VR experience then using GO, really next level. Don't spend your money on the GO - better wait, accumulate some money and buy Quest. Also you can play SteamVR games via VirtualDesktop or via Link - another level of game quality then on the ARM (native Quest games). Really deep black color cause of OLED display in Quest.Not very comfortable straps - need some improvements.
review_title: Worth it. Buy it to understand what is VR.

one_reviews_text: Paid the price for a new system.. but when I received the system.. there were scuffs on the headset and someone else's profile was logged in. So I paid full price for a used system.  Absolutely ridiculous
Awesome. It’s fun

My kids and I have so much fun taking turns using the headset and there’s such a variety of games and apps to choose from. I like the fact it keeps them moving. My son will actually work up a sweat wielding a light saber.
My son bought this for himself with money he earned working over the summer. He still loves it!!
Great standalone vr. 3 to 4 hours batt life but you can use the charge cable while playing for inf charge. Controls are good and video quality is nice. Just needs more games.

Highly sought after item during quarantine. Only took four days (one day early). Very happy with seller! I can't speak for the VR set just yet It's still Mint condition in the package. I'm so excited!
Sure the games are not at flashy as the PC base VR, but the mobility more than makes up for this.  Oculus should be really proud of this one.
This VR set works perfectly and our boys and their friends have gotten lots of fun out of it!
No cables to hookup. I hate the fact that the system crashes a lot with some games and VR chat. Battery last roughly an hour
Easy and painless to set up, or to setup again for a different location.A device that magically transforms you into a myriad of different worlds...
review_title: Easy to setup and use. Its just magic.

one_reviews_text: Very addicting. Awesome so far. We use it everyday. Battery drains faster on games then 360 videos.
Be a time traveler.
This is the most fun you can have with VR.  It is a little expensive, but you get an experience unlike anything else currently available.

 My son is in the midst of a bone marrow transplant for a multiple-relapsed leukemia. After 7 weeks of hospitalization, in the same room with the same surroundings, Oculus Quest has been an incredible break from this same-sights, same-sounds reality. It's amazing!We clear the room, pushing the hospital bed to the side and then after setting our "safe zone" in which he can walk, he is immediately transported to a new world. He hasn't been interested in getting up to go on walks because that feels like work, but to put on the Oculus Quest gear and go scuba diving, or engage in a lightsaber duel, gun battle, or just explore Machu Pichu, he will get up until his legs are too exhausted to go on. The therapists and physicians are blown away at the treatment benefit of Oculus Quest in this environment!Oculus Quest just works. Once the boundaries are set (where the Quest shows a black and white view of the room and you can trace out where the floor and walls of your safe zone are) you are free to walk around (not just look around) inside your virtual world. You get sucked in and can easily forget that the new world you are in is not real. I've tried to sit on the virtual furniture more than once. The graphics are not high resolution, but they are high enough. It's obvious that with increased computational power and development, this is the future of gaming and probably even of remote work and online classes/meetings. But for now, I am so grateful for this technology to help my son get out of the hospital room even while he is confined to it, to be a distraction where we can travel the world and even jump into a galaxy long long ago far far way.
review_title: For My Hospitalized Son: A Lifesaver

one_reviews_text: I didn't buy my Quest through Amazon but I just have to say its my duty as an Amazon citizen and fan of this platform to say...it rocks.About a year ago I spent a little money to get my home computer propped up enough to run Microsoft Mixed Reality (MMR) - realizing that a Vive or a Oculus would have probably been a better experience and that I was just "tasting" the experience.  I didn't have the cash to layout for a hefty graphics card, beefy computer and to buy the visors.  The MMR experience was "okay" but being tethered was a pain and I can't really say I was floored by the experience.  Also I feel Microsoft has moved on and is abandoning (shock) the platform.  But you know what?  That's okay because Quest is here.The Quest is something special.  I was up and playing in 5 minutes.  No loading drivers, no fiddling with multiple cables, no ensuring my drivers are up to date, and no crossing my fingers that I can run that next game.  Every member of the family is wowed by the experience.  The out-of-box experiences are simply put....awe inspiring.  Even setup is a technological wonder.  It makes me giggle...it makes my kids dance...it even got my wife to dance with a virtual robot.  Heck, my brother bought one based on my cooing and HIS family is now enamored and addicted.Pros:- No wires- Room scale experiences- It just works; setup is actually in itself awe-inspiring.  Somehow the device keeps track of your play area...by you pointing your controller on the ground and painting where you will play while you wear the visor (i.e. built in camera).  If you have anything close to a 6x6 area (or greater) you have room for a "room-scale" experience without tether.- Built in sound (or bring your own headphones)- You can connect a controller if a game needs it (got an old xbone sitting around?  use its controller)- Comes with a glasses expander.  Speaking of glasses...I can wear mine without difficulty with the Quest...but there is an expander.  I scratched the heck out a pair of glasses with my MMR device.  No problems here.- The visor hugs your face like an infant alien.  Pretty comfortable for me.  Maybe after an 60-90 minutes I'll adjust or take a break.  Also...Built-in adjustment for horizontal pupil alignment. (again not all VR visors have this - looking at you cheap MMR Lenovo device).  That helps if you were blessed with "non-standard" pupil distances.- You can connect to a VR ready PC with the new Link capability and play PC based RIFT games (say whaaaat?).  That expands capability if you want to have an ambilocal cord experience with the already existing RIFT game ecosystem.- You can cast to Chromecast compatible devices what you are playing.- You could, if you wanted, side load games (i.e. Minecraft for example)- You can watch 3D videos from Oculus, YouTube VR or others.- The visor has mic....in social games you can TALK TO PEOPLE and they talk to you while you play say, a game of table tennis.- There are at least 50-100 experiences/games out of the box (wasn't the case for MMR) from shooters, scary experiences, meditative experiences, movies, connection to YouTube VR, etc.  More to come for sure.- in 2020 purportedly hand tracking (i.e. you will not need the controllers for some experiences at some point) is coming out.- Quest is selling so well at present its making hardware sales for Facebook soar.  Must better than other visors.  These hard sales means more interest in the platform by developers and thus more games being ported/created for the experience- I believe you can side load not just games but content (like videos) but have not explored thatCons- Hmm...hard pressed- You will eventually want to buy some games.  Games are little more expensive than Oculus Go but not overly expensive at between $10-30 a pop. $30 for the more meaty games.- Yes, graphics are a bit muted compared to the water-cooled behemoths used to drive traditional VR...but your not going to care because the experience is THAT good.- Personally, I like longer running games (like 40+hours).  You are dealing with a phone-based processor so...I may have to wait a while for Skyrim on Quest (ha ha).- $400; cost of a low end PC- Chromecast...I don't have one but I hear if you have a supported device it is stable(ish).  Streaming to my Android via Oculus app works for about 3 seconds for me then freezes pretty consistently.  I see this pretty common.  So, jury is out on this one feature for me unless they fix it at some point.Hope this helped somebody.  Enjoy!

one_reviews_text: I've been on this ride from the beginning of CV1 days, I followed the Kickstarter but wanted to wait for a consumer product so I didn't join in. When the CV1 was out, I planned out my PC build as I was going to start messing around with VR dev work and had an idea in my head of how I would find the VR experience from seeing videos online. I thought VR would be revolutionary and once I got my hands on the CV1, the fun began. I enjoyed games like DCS and Onward the most and messed with the software and hardware settings as much as possible. There was a major issue I ran into during CV1 however that has yet to be addressed and it's one of visual clarity. Even after having gone through other headsets like the Oculus Go, Samsung Odyssey +, and now this Oculus Quest, I find myself at the mercy of tech that just doesn't seem to be quite there.The Quest is running two OLED panels with the same panel resolution as the Ody+, which while impressive, does not rectify the clarity problem. Worse still is the fact render resolution is not the same as the panel resolution. Having messed with render resolution on PCVR, I can say that rendering below the native resolution of a screen does not produce good results as you might imagine. If I'm not mistaken, it is also a good idea for PCVR to render slighting above the native screen resolution to better deal with the issues that come up when transferring the image the panels give though the lenses and into your eyes, not to mention the better perceived sharpness rendering higher than the panel produces in general. The Quest uses software workarounds to deal with its limited hardware and this is quite understandable. Having messed with the Ody+ and finding the resolution still not good enough with a PC behind it, I had to temper my expectations. What did I find?Fit/finish: The materials and design remind me of the CV1 and this is a very good thing for me given I really found myself loving most everything about the CV1. You have solid feeling plastics all round with a solid implementation of a matte finish(thank God as I despise glossy plastic with a passion). The face interface is cushiony and easy to remove for maintenance and they stayed with the thin and light baseball cap headband design. While I didn't have an issue with the weight and played long sessions, I did find CV1 had a better fit on my head but I was overall happy. It's good Oculus kept most of the work for this product in house as compared to the Rift S as it shares many similarities with CV1 which is great.Screens/Lenses: All good things come to an end and for this product, this is the most painful aspect of my experience. With expectations limited and hesitation removed, I decided to give this headset a shot. While I did purchase a PC for VR, the need for high fidelity graphics is not really on the current table of wants. I purchase the power to simply push as many pixels as possible given my initial reading of how VR headsets would work, you're magnifying the screens after all to cover a large FOV compared to your standard monitor. I could care less if games used PS2 graphics, I just want some measure of clarity that's acceptable and this won't be the same for everyone. What I found was still a pixelated/blurry experience, Oculus software magic didn't overcome the hardware limits enough here sadly. We are gaining a good jump from CV1, this is the same resolution the Ody+ and Vive Pro use after all, but you must also know that we are not dealing with an RGB stripe arrangement found in LCD headsets. The lack of an RGB stripe arrangement, as only currently found in OLED form on the PSVR if I'm not mistaken, combined with the limited hardware, gives you a sub optimal visual experience. Things that are close are fuzzy and pixelated while things moving just a bit out become a blurry mess quite quickly. There are ways game designers can work within these limits and still produce great experiences like Creed and BeatSaber. I found I could enjoy myself with good game design but same as with CV1, I just could not ignore constantly looking at a world that made me think I forgot to put on my contacts/glasses, but I kept on playing. In comparison the the CV1, the lenses seem to do a better job at handling god rays and we are dealing with OLED screens which produce great contrast. Even with OLED screens, true black isn't something to expect but we still gain quite a noticeable contrast boost vs LCD. I am happy to see the Quest also includes manual IPD which is truly a dick move to have removed from the Rift S BTW. Given my high IPD, I was able to set up the lenses exactly where they needed to be and unlike the Go, I did not suffer almost immediate eye strain. We are dealing with a lower refresh rate on the Quest but I can happily say this did not cause discomfort for me so I see it as an absolute win given the limited hardware.Tracking: I came in not expecting much with the tracking outside the volume the cameras cover and had no surprises in this regard as I witnessed my hands snap and float around. One area I however held hope for was for tracking performance inside the cameras view. I found Jasons defense of their move to inside out tracking on the PC side quite worrying but I still see inside out as a necessary sin given the added simplicity it brings to mobile and the need for VR to get off the ground. Having played Creed, Robo Recall, and Beat Saber the most, I noticed my hands experienced small shaking and unstable tracking from time to time. This also happened outside of games as I messed around in the home enviroment and with the guardian system. I attempted resets, switching the tracking setting, and different rooms but this never truly went away. My experience with the guardian system has also been hit and miss with the Quest sometimes remembering the room and other times not. I did have my living room mostly blank but Oculus support assured me this wouldn't be an issue. While I could not correct the instability before I returned my headset, I was still able to enjoy multiple games for the most part but given my solid experience with CV1 tracking, my impressions were hampered. There's a good chance this wouldn't be as much of an issue if you're new to VR so keep that in mind, the overall experience might make up for it. For sure, my experience with the Quest tracking was much better than WMR so I'm happy they added the extra cameras and placed them as they did.UPDATE: Oculus has updated the headset a couple times since this review and tracking both inside the cameras visible area and outside has seen good performance gains, It's still not as good as the 3 camera CV1 experience I had but a solid update no less. The headset also seems to do a better job at remember my multiple guardian setups.Sound: I've dealt with some high end gear, gear many would deem ludicrous to own and I'd agree with them. From high end headphones to high end in ears, I've tried some highly regarded products such as the Stax 009, Sony MDR-EX1000, and JH Audio 13. The only speakers I've owned where JBL 305P MK11's(dang glossy plastic) with the accompanying subwoofer but currently have Airpods and Philip L2's I attached a bluetooth module to with command strips and a short Fiio cable, it works what can I say. The CV1 over ear implementation surprised me as it provided a well rounded solution with good bass for those in game times you needed it. The Quest solution is quite frankly a major disappointment for me and unlike inside out tracking, I don't see this as a necessary sin given how easy the CV1 solution was to use. I'd simply guess this is mostly to cut cost rather than remove friction for the customer but there's no way for me to know for sure. While you miss out on much of the bass, you do get fairly good positional sound so all is not lost. I've seen people DIY solutions to imitate the CV1 solution on the Quest but really I would have preferred it if Oculus at least offered an in house solution to this problem.UPDATE: I tried using IEM through the audio ports and the ports are noisy which is disappointing.Conclusion: The choice to go with OLED screens while surprising to me given the cost considerations they were working with, provide good contrast but worse clarity. I might have personally preferred LCD given the trade offs unless of course they decided to pay the cost of RBG OLED on their end. Inside out tracking while limited in performance, has proven to be a necessity in my experience with this device. There are no extra boxes or wires to manage and friction is greatly reduced for it. The controllers are nicely made if a bit harder to handle given their top heavy nature and battery cover that tends to slide out of place. Compromises are the name of the game and my hope is Carmack and gang continue to push out as much performance and polish as they can because this is truly the best platform currently out to introduce people to VR. You have a wireless and polished all in one package for $399, I'd say it's definitely worth a shot. Given the current Quest specs and my experience, I have a strong feeling Quest 2 will be the version I keep.
review_title: Best introduction to VR to date, not enough clarity for me to keep.

one_reviews_text: Ok if you’re looking to get into VR, I can give you a model comparison so you endup with the right one for you.This is not a paid review, just my honest opinion from experiences with them.Will appreciate if you click if you indeed found this helpful.The Oculus Go is an entry level headset.It does not require a computer to run and is this wireless.Affordable.Would be great for kids under 13.It’s not too complex or high end.Easy to pickup and get the hang of.There are no external cameras so it’s more of a stationary headset which is ironic given its name. (Go as coined in that this headset is wireless, it does NOT need a stand alone computer to tether to.)Will not get you moving around or exercising.Had one controller which is basic and easy however limiting.Can not upgrade. Good to get your toes wet.Not for hardcore gamers. Lighter than Quest by a bit.Samsung Gear Powered by OculusVery affordable.Does not require a computer to tether to.DOES require a smartphone to power it.By not putting all the internal to power it, they were able to make a very cheap and light headset.Will use your phones battery while in use.Phone can not be used while the headset is using it.Requires a compatible phone.Better phone will yield slightly better experience.Not for hardcore gamers. Good to get your feet wet at a cheap price tag if you have a compatible smart phone.Pretty light weight without the phone attached.Oculus Quest-Probably my favorite and best headset for the average person.This is a big upgrade from the two choices mentioned above.This headset has better specs, faster, better screen, visuals/graphics.This headset is ideal for casual gamers.This headset is good for most ages. Adults will appreciate this over the two listed above.The major downside vs. the two above is cost.Quest costs significantly more than the Go and Gear. In my opinion it is worth it for me but it isn’t for everyone.Quest has TWO controllers which ad a bit of complexity for some but make use much more fluid and in depth.Quest had external sensors/cameras that allow it to sense the environment around it.You are able to move and it will be reflected in game. This headset will have you moving and exercising depending on the game/app you’re in. Quest has the ability to define room boundaries as to not run in to or hit surrounding objects or walls.Quest is newer than both Gear and Go.Quest is fairly heavy as it is fairly high specs and is not tethered/powered by a computer or phone. It is wireless but a bit heavier as a result. Added weight did not bother me much but it may to some.Oculus Rift- This is the top of the line most immersive VR experience Oculus offers.This is for hardcore gamers or those where cost is not a factor in deciding on a VR headset. This has all the bells and whistles but at a cost. In my opinion a huge cost, both financially and more importantly to me limitations, mainly in movement and freedom.Rift requires an external computer to power it.This requires cords and as a result is not wireless and limits freedom and movements.It is possible to get tangled when fully immersed.You must have a fairly high end PC to run this well. A dinosaur pc you got on Black Friday probably won’t cut it and will not have fluid or quality gameplay.This would be a good choice for a hardcore gamer who already has a high end pc and would not need to purchase a computer just to power this headset.The graphics are stunning and your experience can be upgraded slightly by upgrading the pc powering it.To me I did not like how it’s not something you could just throw on quickly and you’re in the VR world. You had to make an effort and set aside time not just jump in and out for a few minutes. Not something you could travel with unless there is a high end pc near you.Overall the most graphically stunning and realistic.Storage size/GB’s - I have been asked which storage size I’d recommend. I can say that the lower storage will be fine for most. For those who get lots of games/apps, may want to upgrade storage size.To me personally, I’d probably get the smaller storage and just use the savings towards a future headset in a few years once they have improved drastically. Just my opinion.Please remember to click if you found this helpful

Was so interested in the VR world, given I play Playstation games and pc games once in a while. I wanted to totally immerse myself in the VR world and escape, Similar to that of Ready Player One. The first time I tried this thing, was absolutely mind blowing. Sure not the smoothest of gameplay, and very similar to strapping a smartphone that’s heavy over your face, but in regards to playing this for no joke 30 minutes, I had a severe ocular migraine, the hospital wants to call it a small T.I.A. Or mini stroke, but whatever it was it wasn’t a cool experience. I have had them as a kid in the past and now that I’m 25, I thought they’d be gone by now since I had been headache free for 2 years. Now all of a sudden it has come back and this time with a vengeance. Anytime I strap this puppy on, I get an immediate headache. I do not recommend for anyone that has suffered these headaches.
review_title: DO NOT REPEAT DO NOT GET IF YOU GET MIGRAINES

one_reviews_text: My husband and I bought 2 Oculus Quest sets. We saw a commercial and figured we would get them for Christmas gifts for my daughter and her boyfriend who is a gamer. My son and his wife have systems too but neither couple have virtual reality. My daughters boy friend stated that he has been dying to try Oculus  Rift. He plays on his computer when he isn’t at work. I mentioned to my daughter that there is a “Wireless” one called Oculus Quest. My husband and I bought 2 Oculus Quests to give them as Christmas gifts. Then we were so curious, we sent for a Oculus Quest for ourselves. I have to state how simple it was to set up. We didn’t even need a PC! Just my  I-phone and Wi fi! I downloaded the Oculus Quest AP and followed the easy directions for instal. So easy! My husband and I purchased the 128 GB. Let me tell you, he and I are in our 60s and we are amazed by this. It was like becoming part of the game. We have no words to discribe what this is like. You have to experience it for yourself! ~ We initially had trouble with the “ guardian”. We kept going outside our game perimeter. Then, my husband figured out how this is resolved. You just use the toggle control to bring it toward you. It moves the game in closer, so there is no reason to move outside one’s boundary ( guardian). It took a few times for him to figure that out. That was during the Vader Immortal  game.  Both of us feel like playing Oculus Quest is like entering into another world. I enjoy playing Quill. It is challenging and beautifully done.  I highly recommend Oculus Quest! I cannot wait for Christmas when our children and grandkids will get their sets. I can not wait for them to experience it!  The games are great.

The product is making a noise and the handsets did not work. First I contacted Amazon for support. They said they could not help so they were online chatting with Microsoft Microsoft so they could not help so then they reached out to oculus. Finally Amazon said we are going to send you a link For oculus so you can troubleshoot from there. The link was to the basic Amazon page which was not helpful. I reached out to oculus and they could not do a phone call. My child has autism and cannot read and has difficulty expressing himself. I beg somebody to please call me. They were just online chat which frustrated things because my son could not communicate properly to me and I could not communicate to them. Because I am not a technical person I just said can we please exchange this or send it back for repairs. Ultimately they could not figure out what was going wrong. They said someone would get back to us within six weeks. It is a shame because I have purchased so much from Amazon. Amazon said this is an item they cannot return or exchange it has to go through the manufacture. My son has been withdrawn for about four hours. These sessions last a good 3 1/2 hours with no resolution. It’s very disappointing because I have had such a positive experience with Amazon. I’ve tried multiple times to get back in touch thinking maybe I just reached the wrong person. I am not getting any information back. Just people pushing me two numbers that are not picking up or support that takes weeks to get back to you
review_title: No answers for a broken set and no return offered

one_reviews_text: This is my third recent VR headset. I also have a PSVR and an original Oculus Rift, so I have some basis for comparison.I wanted this because it's both a standalone headset *and* it can now connect to your PC via Oculus Link, which gives it all the same functionality as the Rift. So it's a clear upgrade in that sense; it just does more than the Rift, being that it can also be used (with its own dedicated apps and games) without the PC, and even when running PC games it does not require external sensors. Since all the wires the other VR systems require are my big pet peeve about VR in general, I thought the Quest would be the perfect solution.And if this is your first experience with VR, definitely prepare to be blown away. Modern VR just in general is almost a life-changing experience, and the Quest is no different. The graphics are to the point where it's easy to immerse yourself in the content. The Quest has a little higher resolution than the Rift and a little lower refresh rate; overall it's kind of a wash IMO. It looks pretty similar to me. But both look great overall.Compared to the PSVR, both are obviously higher quality in terms of the image, although PSVR holds its own and is still more than good enough to immerse yourself in. PSVR also has better lenses than either the Rift or the Quest, both of which have obvious "god rays", where the light bounces around and reflects off the inside of the lenses. I had hoped the Quest would fix this issue, but it hasn't. Its lenses do look a little different than the Rift - the light rays are kind of evenly distributed rather than all concentrated in the middle as on the Rift, but there's just as much of it. PSVR doesn't have this at all.There are two medium-sized caveats with the Quest:1) It's uncomfortable! Oculus is going backwards on this. The Rift was comfortable *enough*, but not very much so... I expected the Quest to be an improvement after 4 or so years of extra development. This is a really big issue for VR - it has to be comfortable. And the Quest is just not. It's extremely front-heavy, for one thing, and its head strap seems somehow even less well designed than the Rift's (which was already kind of hacky, with velcro and whatnot). It's meant to go down further on the back of your head and grab the entire circumference of your skull, but in practice it just slides forward no matter what I do. And when it slides forward, it presses really hard on your face.There are accessories you can get to alleviate this, which makes it clear too that it's a real issue (if it weren't, companies wouldn't be profiting from it). But that's an extra expense, and something I'm going to have to use trial and error with some of these products to fix.If you're wondering, the PSVR is very comfortable and it's supposedly the "low end" option these days, but I can wear it for hours without even thinking about it. It doesn't press against your face at all. The Quest I can wear for maybe 30 minutes before it's unbearable. Other VR companies need to just copy Sony - they've got it right.2) It's missing any sort of headphones. Again, you can fix this by buying something extra - you can either use regular earbuds (though the cord will probably get in the way) or you can buy special earbuds just for the Quest with short cords. But I feel like this is a major omission - VR just doesn't feel right when listening through speakers. It takes you out of the immersive world. This reeks of cost-cutting - the Rift had some pretty good headphones attached directly to it. The PSVR at least came with a set of special earbuds with the right length asymmetrical cord (I eventually upgraded to something more like the Rift has, headphones attached to the headset side rails, but it at least came with *something* so you didn't need to spend extra money right off the bat).I'm sure I'm getting more critical as someone who's on his third VR headset. But that's the thing - VR should be maturing, and while the Quest is awesome for being standalone *and* PC linkable, in other important ways it's a regression, with extra purchases required to fix its issues. I just expect better at this point, and we all should. These systems are not inexpensive, nor are they new tech anymore. And Oculus is not some tiny little indie company; they are owned by Facebook. (Oh, also? They *really* want you to log in with Facebook now. I tried logging in with just my email address, but they linked my email address with my Facebook account and logged me in with Facebook anyway. You have to manually unlink your account, but you will "lose access to certain functions" if you do so.)Still, I'm probably going to end up selling my Rift simply because it doesn't do as much as the Quest. I'll bite the bullet and buy what I need to buy to bring the Quest up to standard (I've already ordered Quest-specific earbuds; some sort of comfort solution will come next). Once I do that, I think I'll be happier with it than with the Rift, especially because I can finally get rid of the rat's nest of cables going to my PC (HDMI and three sensor cables), and only connect the Quest when I need to in order to play PC-based games. That was the original goal; I just thought the out of the box experience would get me there, and it didn't.
review_title: Cool, but as a VR veteran, more caveats than I expected

one_reviews_text: To start off i was very impressed with the Oculus Quest. I've never owned a VR headset before even though my PC is capable of handling VR. I hesitated on buying a headset for a long time due to the room tracking sensors. The Quest doesn't need any sensors and has set itself apart from others in this respect. I LOVE the ability this thing has to set up a safe play area almost anywhere, truly a game changer.Headset:The headset is really adjustable and having tested it out with 10+ people now i can say that normal/large/small heads can all comfortably adjust the headset to fit them. I've introduced many of my friends to VR for the first time on this headset and they are blown away by the ease of learning to use the headset and the tutorial. Its a great way for someone to get into VR for the first time. Can't wait to test it on my parents :)Graphics:The graphics are not phenomenal on the headset but keep in mind this is running on its own steam (processing power/battery) and keeping that in mind the graphics are great for what it is. Is it cutting edge graphics? No. But with no wires this headset is truely immersive any everyone i've shown it to has 'forgotten where they are' meaning the graphics are good enough for total immersion in the VR world. When my friends take it off they look like they just came out of the Matrix "holy s***" is the top thing i hear when they take it off and i'd agree.BatteryThe battery claims are true. 2 hours is normal on a charge but you can charge while playing so if you really wanted to play longer you could connect a battery pack to yourself and after a full week of use 2 hours is normally plenty for me. For what this thing is capable of, 2 hours of play is really impressive to me.ScreenThe screen is decent. there is a slight visible bit of pixelation but, again, it never takes away from the immersion. Brightness is good and the colors are great as well, no gripes there. It's solidGamesThe games list is growing every day for this and i know some VR elitists will say it doesn't have enough but for an entry level VR things things has plenty to offer in terms of games. I invite you to look the titles up on your own but i've had a ton of fun so far gaming and using multiplayer in the one zombie game i own was flawless. The microphone also worked very wellSoundVery good, very good indeed. Can outside people hear the speakers? Of course. But when you have it on the sound is great. Several friends have asked where is the sound even coming from because it works so well. Its totally directional and you can tell without looking where the character speaking is in the VR world. Very impressed.ValueShop around... please do. For $400 this thing is an extremely good value. You can surf the web, play games, watch 360 Youtube vids, cast to a phone/tv, watch movies. What else can immerse you in a VR world for $400?  Nothing i've found as of today. I had decent expectations for the Quest and i was blown away by the value. I was not dissappointed in any way and i'd gladly make this purchase again. One of the best things i've bought in years! Rarely do i have zero regrets on a purchase. This is one of those zero regret purchases.Final thoughtsIf you are on the fence about this headset... pull the trigger. This will be the first big step in bringing VR into every home. From ease of use to the quality of build i could not be more happy. I didn't buy from Amazon to ensure i had it in my hands on day one, and a week later of heavy VR time i regret nothing. The Quest delivers what it promised. A stand alone VR headset that can be used almost anywhere. I love showing people who have never used VR this thing, they are blown away.  This is what the future of VR looks like. Stand alone, solid performance.I hope this review was helpful to you

My Glasses got scratched by Oculus lens rubbing against them. I have the included spacer installed. The spacer should be thicker. I have very thin glasses, yet the lenses within Goggles still we're close enough to ruin my expensive progressive glasses. A large rub mark 1/4 inch by 1/4 inch is now on center of my glasses. It ruined both lenses of my glasses. As for my glasses getting ruined I'm bummed, they were expensive.  Also the Quest now has small rub marks on each lense. I would like to have the lenses replaced.  It would be nice if the headset had a focus wheel for each lens, then one would not need to wear their glasses unless they have a strong stigmatisim.

I am kinda in love with this thing! This review is going to jump all over the place in the most annoying fanboy way possible.I have only used my Oculus Gear and the VR roller coasters that popped up in malls in the mid 90s. Oculus Quest is a massive upgrade from the Oculus Gear. There is no comparison to be honest. With Gear, you could only turn your head to look around the virtual space which led to migraines and nausea for me. 15 to 20 minutes was all I could comfortably stand in Gear. With Quest, I never wanna take it off.  I don't know what the technical term for it is, but the ability to actually MOVE through a space instead of just turning my head to look at it completely remedied my VR headaches and nausea issues.It is immersive as hell. Several times I found myself attempting to lean on a table or countertop. It's...I don't know. You kinda need to try it for yourself. I think BestBuy may have them to demo.The graphics are nothing to complain about. If you are expecting photorealistic graphics and a 4k display zapped in your eyes from these teensy screens, you'd be better avoiding all VR for awhile. The picture quality I've experienced has been clear and clean. The screen door effect from Gear is not at all present. I've read negative reviews saying it is pixely, but that is not what I am seeing. Yes, you are able to see some pixels, but this had in no way negatively impacted my experience. Not 4k by any means, but still a great picture.For watching movies, it is fantastic! The Gear changed how I fly. I am a nervous flyer and using Gear to watch movies helped me escape the plane panic I usually feel. I can't wait for my next flight with Quest.The ability to be in a giant movie theater by myself while in the comfort of my bed is decadent. The ability to Matrix dodge bullets in Super Hot is godlike. The ability to mark out your safe play area with the Guardian system is game changing. No cord jutting out of the back of your head. I mean, I'm in love.The only complaints I have so far are the battery life and the discomfort of the back strap. The battery lasts about 2.5 hours of playtime, but you can charge it while you play. I have an external battery pack that I keep it plugged to and just stick the extra battery in my back pocket. It has worked really well. I may have played 6 hours with the battery...  For the strap discomfort, I bought a counterweight for the back of the device to offset the weight of the front. That has worked surprisingly well.There are about 50 titles for it right now. Job Simulator, Super Hot, Apex Construct, Accounting+, and Journey of the Gods I highly recommend. If you like drawing or sculpting, absolutely get Tilt Brush. It is just incredible. There are tons of titles already confirmed for release soon, and Oculus said it will be backwards compatible with your Oculus Go titles by the end of the year.So that is my all over the place review as of now. Fanboying so hard. I'm totally in love.
review_title: I am deeply in love with my Quest

one_reviews_text: Dear Oculus, it pains me to give this a two star rating. I am so impressed with the Quest. From the packaging, to the cell app set up, ergonomics, you have created a sexy piece of TechArt. I was in absolute agony to return it.I bought this for my son, he loves playing games on Steam and watching YouTubers play games. He wanted to play the VR games available on Steam. Unfortunately, he couldn't do that with Quest. Steams website indicated my PC isn't fast enough to handle VR, I thought Quest would be the perfect solution.From what I'm learning, it appears Quest speaks an Android language, thus able to process and use games and apps written for Android. The games my son wants to play are written for PC and not available in the Oculus game library. This was a heartbreaking moment, because you really have created a beautiful VR environment. I can imagine this game unit as the future, but currently the game choices are just too limited, and pricey.

If I could give ZERO stars, I would.Appalling customer service. They just keep pushing you around from their chat service to their email responses.I bought the 128 GB Quest, but because of Covid, was unable to fire up the system until June 13th. I immediately spent $239.99 over the next couple of days on apps and games. I also spent money on other after market accessories like head pads, beat sabers and other stuff. Maybe another $150 worth of kit. So over $1000 all told.To my immense dismay the headset had a fault from the get go. A green slash line across the left lens. And it made using the system unbearable. I tried to fix this issue - looking in forums etc, but without success. After my third time (TOTAL) using my Oculus, I decided to reach out to their customer service on June 18th. I was told to send pictures of the damaged lens. Which I did. Then I was told to mail in the headset. Which I did. They received it on June 27th. I was told that I would receive news within 2-3 days. When no news had arrived by August 9th, I reached out again. I was told I would have news soon.When I finally chased Oculus for an update on my order status on Aug 19th, saying that I was fed up with being in the dark about the status of my headset and now wanted not just a replacement but to be compensated for the inconvenience… rather conveniently / mysteriously, an abrupt order was made that very day to despatch a replacement headset to me. It was almost as though they’d forgotten all about me.I immediately saw from the email of this “order” that the headset would be a refurbished one.I wrote to them right away saying that this would not be an acceptable solution as far as I was concerned.The fact that anyone at Oculus thinks its remotely acceptable to palm off a second hand product on a customer who has just spent $648.27 on a brand new system is incredible. It’s not as if I’ve had my headset for months. It was literally out of the box new.I don’t care if the refurb headset has been painstakingly renovated and the strap and face cushion has been replaced. It’s an older product. Possibly an earlier generation version of the Quest. Either way, it’s considered used. For all I know it had a fault with it at some point. I have no idea how it’s been treated and how old it really is. I can see from the headset cover that it’s more faded than my new one was. Batteries and other components erode with use. It’s just a fact. Which is why refurbished units don’t have the same value online. That tells you everything you need to know.I paid a lot of money for a brand new Oculus. Would you accept a polished and serviced second hand car with mileage on the clock and a missing damage report history as a replacement for your brand new, never been driven car? No, you would not.While I allowed Oculus the latitude of using Covid as an excuse for the 2 month lag it took to “solve” the problem, I have received no reciprocal respect or sensitivity to my situation. They refused a refund on the system on the basis that it was more than 30 days until the problem was reported (despite the usage data supporting my case that i reported the problem as soon as i started using the system), but the even bigger kick in the nuts was when they told me they would not be refunding any of my apps or games ($239,99) despite most of them having been unused - BECAUSE IT WAS MORE THAN 2 MONTHS SINCE THEY WERE DOWNLOADED. The 2 months they had my headset. Incredible.In most instances, when you have let a customer down with the quality of your product, industry standard practice is to go above and beyond. To not just resolve the problem, but to leave the customer feeling even better about the experience of dealing with your company. I paid more than $880 for a premium quality experience and got the polar opposite of that. Instead of thinking “How can we turn this disappointing experience into a positive one?” Oculus have treated me with complete contempt.Their support service is a black box designed to exhaust customers into submission. No accountability. No option to speak to an actual human. No supervisors. Everyone parroting the same corporate speak. I’ve been trapped in an endless cycle of chat support, email, chat support, email…DO NOT BUY AN OCULUS PRODUCT. YOU WILL REGRET IT.

There's a lot to love about the Quest, and a few nagging issues.  The thing looks amazing, something from a movie prop department. The controllers are reminiscent of classic SF space ships. It charges via the included cord - really, really long USB-C to USB-C. It's just - fun. Especially seeing the looks people have when trying it out.I've been using this for a few days now, gone through a few charges, tried games and videos, watched Netflix and viewed my own 360 photos and 360 videos.Setup takes about 20 minutes.  It requires having either an Oculus account, or a FaceBook account (remember, FB owns Oculus.) Everything is done over your smart phone or tablet. Make sure your phone/tablet's WiFi is on - the files are big and can suck up your cell data fast. WiFi has to be on when installing the software, but not downloading - I made that mistake and chewed up a ton of data. I also downloaded the PC software, as the Oculus site links to is. But the Quest is not one of the supported headsets.  I can see the point - the Quest IS a stand alone gaming device.Gameplay: The tracking is flawless. It's amazing. Truly immersive. It's difficult to NOT drop a controller when dropping a weapon, or to want to try walking up to a window to look out and so on. The demo/training apps are a blast. I did not notice any lag or other issues.  The Oculus controllers are basically a traditional gamepad broken in two. Quick to adapt to and learn to use. Traditional trigger, bumper and joystick placement. However you can only play games you purchase from the Oculus store - $10 and up. Average $30.Watching video:  Again, really fun. Netflix gives you a living room setup that looks like it's in a $10 million mansion in the mountains . I keep wanting to walk around or grab the cup of cocoa and have a taste. Where it shines is 360 content on YouTube. WOW. No stuttering, smooth. 8K video is mind blowing (remember you're looking at only a small portion of the video sphere, so 4K can actually look fuzzy.)  You're only looking at a 2K window of an 8K 360 video as you look around.  I have several 360 videos I shot over the past year on YouTube and it was really fun to watch these - and see myself walking around. And seeing my bald spot first hand. THAT part was not fun. Skydiving, Scuba diving with sharks, flying through Notre Dame. The Dali museum video. All worth watching and sharing.Video quality. If you're looking at video or playing a game with really bright and dark areas, there's sometimes visible light streaking. Same when trying to read text.  The lenses are a "fresnel" type - one side is smooth the other has concentric circles. These can distort the text and create bright spots that look like reflections - I kept checking to make sure there was no light leaking in the mask.
