Finally tried it in a dimmer room before I realized the effect was inside the headset. It's especially obvious watching Netflix.PC use: Not officially supported, you can find youtube videos on it. It can be done but it's more of a work in progress and not from Oculus.  With this workaround you can play Steam VR games, but not with full support. Some buttons don't work or are swapped, etc. The PC software from Oculus does not support the Quest.Fit: Does anyone have a nose this big? Looking down, I see my feet through the gap.  I finally put a piece of felt inside to cover it. The size adjustments are quick and easy, but it is really front heavy. I noticed the weight after around 15 minutes. It also runs HOT. Ever watch a video or play a demanding game on your phone and feel the battery heat up? Same thing. One advantage to this - the inside of the mask stays warm and dry so the lenses don't fog up.  I did find that my forehead constantly bumped against the lenses when removing the mast or putting it on. It took some practice to (mostly) avoid this. Grip the head straps on the back of your head. Grip the headset. Pull the headset forward off your face (there's some springy give that's designed for this) pull the straps up, then the mask forward.Sound: Pretty darn incredible. I did have some issues on a couple of YouTube videos, but for the most part was fantastic. Since it's basically mini-speakers on either side of the headset, others can gear it as well, and you can still hear ambient sounds.  There's 1/8" headset jacks on either side of the headset, and any earbuds will work. Many headphones will also work - my Steel Series gaming headphones are perfect. My Sony Noise cancelling ones are too big.Casting: If your device supports Chromecast, you can mirror what you see to the device.  Our smart TV has Chromecast built-in. Works amazingly well. Same with my Android tablet and phone. The TV would be fun for gaming parties.Other comments: The video passthrough is . . . unsettling. You see a high contrast black and white immersive image of your surroundings. You can walk around, grab things, etc. The controllers look totally normal though. The scale is a little off. It reminds me of walking around after drinking a big glass of Merlot. But it is also really slick and fun. Setting up the safe/play area is simple. I had to adjust the floor once - initial setup used the location of the controllers. Since they were on my desk, the desk height was set to floor height.  When setting up the play area, watch out for overhang - table tops, countertops, etc. I initially traced around the bases of the cabinets and tables.  So I ran my hands into the overhangs a few times. I picked up a micro-fiber cloth to keep the lenses clean, and ordered a big pair of googly eyes to stick on the front. There's a sensor in the face area that turns off the screens when the headset is removed, and turns them on again automatically when you wear it.Tons of fun, and you're playing while standing up.  You can watch videos sitting down. The FPS shooter demos added a new dimension (pun intended) - you can literally look over your shoulder.  For a stand-alone system, it's incredible.  I just wish they would have included VirtualLink port support, since Oculus is one of the forces behind the technology. But alas the l-o-n-g USB-C cable is just for charging.
review_title: Amazing fun. A stand-alone gaming system - Not for use with computers.

one_reviews_text: Firstly let me just say that I’m a VR enthusiast, I have literally all VR headsets from PSVR Oculus CV1 with three sensors, HTC Vive OG, HTC Vive Pro (with wireless adaptor) purchased Oculus Rift S, and finally Occulus Quest.To sum this up, this is the easiest most convenient most travel friendly VR headset on the market!The occulus Created apps are designed specifically for the headset and the hardware and it’s quite obvious they are beautiful, the conversion apps aren’t as impressive, you can tell all the developer did was cut the graphics and put no effort into polishing it. Vader immortal in itself is worth buying the headset IMO! The library is currently limited but still a nice collection!The tracking is incredible, the performance is incredible the graphics 6/10 compared to Vive Pro 10/10 maxed out with supersampling.In the end it’s a headset I’m proud to show off and bring to friends houses, parties, or just throw on and play a quick game, it’s just so simple? As an example I probably threw it on 10 times today just sporadically? I know it’s new but all the games I’ve played before I was just eager to play without all the fuss, turning on a computer, setting up sensors, tweaking the system for optimal performance? All that’s cut out you just Put it on your head and play! The os is simplified and runs flawless I had zero lock ups, battery life is acceptable, the speakers could Use some amplification but oculus included headphone jacks so you can’t complain?Overall I highly recommend this VR headsets, specifically to anyone new to the world of VR.This is the future of VR, chipsets and mobile processors and GPu are only getting faster, eventually it will all be network driven.Game on! See you in the Oasis
review_title: I have all VR Headsets! This is a nice addition

one_reviews_text: Absolutely amazing. Beat Saber and Pistol Whip have become my cardio. I thought I'd end up playing more PC games using Oculus Link, even for games that are crossbuy, because I usually prefer the best graphics. But I almost exclusively play Quest titles because the freedom of cordless is just too awesome, and while the graphics on PC are certainly better, I never really notice once I get into the game. Some of the games (like Beat Saber) have almost no noticeable graphics drop. Still, the fact Oculus Link even exists makes this a no brainer. This is the single best cost for entertainment purchase I've made in a very long time, and I'd rather spend 2 hours doing cardio in VR than 20 minutes on a treadmill.

We have reached the point where VR is ready for prime time. It's not perfect, but this is a quantum leap that divides the pre-3D era from the VR era.  It's not cheap, but the cost is now comparable to other gaming platforms, within the reach of many consumers. Games are indeed a lot shorter to play through than similar titles on PS4 or PC. But the immersive experience is a totally new feeling and very obviously the way of the future.There are plenty of gripes. Number one is that the headset fogs easily and often. Many games are extremely vigorous to play and you'll be heating up and sweating a lot, which means fog on the viewing lenses.  And the battery life of the wireless headset is short, just a few hours. The controllers also eat AA battery power like crazy and need to be changed every few days.But the experience is incredible.  After playing just a few sessions, I have no interest in returning to regular video games, despite the higher detail and smoother motion.Our family has had a LOT of time to spend playing video games during the quarantine, and Quest has made it so much easier to stay at home. Because we've been underwater, flying over the country, exploring natural wonders, surviving zombie outbreaks, and boxing against Apollo Creed - all in our living room.

I currently have a Vive Pro hooked up to a pretty nice gaming rig... but I just coudln't resist a portable VR solution. I picked up the Quest at a local retailer since Amazon was sold out. I am truly impressed by the quality of this thing. Controllers are high quality and a joy to use. The headset does not seem overly heavy, and is pretty comfortable. The screens themselves are supprisingly clear with minimal screen door effect. Not having wires or any externally required hardware makes the quest a truly portable system, and room scale setup takes no more than a few seconds to setup.The graphical fidelity is pretty dependent on the games themselves. Some games that were designed to be more cartoony and blocky perform very well and look nice n' sharp. Other games that were not designed with these lower specs in mind had to really bring down those graphics, and it's not always as nice as you'd like. Not just regarding the lower quality textures and models, but even lowering the resolution so the game looks fuzzy. Games that do not require this look stunning, and are more enjoyable to play on the quest than even the vive pro, since the wireless gaming experience is just a better one. And some games will simply never make it onto the Quest. But if you're looking for a VR experience that's accessible, portable, and provides an optimal VR experience, there is really no better option than the Quest. And for a price about the same as a standard gaming console, you'll be experiencing a whole new level of gaming immersion without being tethered to an expensive gaming rig. Go get one. You'll be happy you did!

Do not buy!!!!The hardware is great so far.  The support is so bad that I can’t recommend purchasing an oculus quest.  I needed to change the password on my account, when I entered a new password I received the error, “Something went wrong. Please try again.” A meaningless error like this is a programming failure.I tried many different password iterations.  I always get the same error.  I contacted support via chat.  They were not able to help.  The tech said “we need to move you to email.”When I asked what that meant that said they could not escalate my issue until I closed the chat.  And that the “investigation team” only communicates by email. I did not receive any contact for 24 hours after this chat session.  I then reached out again. This is a what I received in response:“We are going to continue looking further into the issue you have expressed. This does not mean that we have stopped working on your issue, just that it will require more time for us to do our investigation.We appreciate your patience and understanding, and we will do our best to contact you back with more information or an update in the next 3-5 business days (from Monday-Friday).Kind Regards, ​​XxxxxxxOculus Support“3-5 days???????This is unacceptable.  This was a gift for my kid so I am going to wait and see what happens.  If not for him I would return the product.There is no circumstance where I would buy this p”device if I knew the support policy was to kick the can to an understaffed department that can’t investigate a login error for a week.
review_title: Do not buy.  The hardware is good, the support system is unacceptable.

one_reviews_text: I have had it now for 10 days. Previously, I did have the PS4 VR so I can compare this Occulus Quest with the PS4 VR.Pros:-It's the most versatile VR headset for a budget because not only can you play games designed for stand alone Quest games, you have the option of linking it via cable to a Game PC to play Occulus RIft games, so it's like two VR headsets in one. Keep in mind that the PS4 VR has the most games and by that I mean quality AAA games but you need a PS4. If you already have a PS4, the PS4 VR is a no brainer, but if you don't have one, then you need to purchase a PS4 which is an added expense.-It's a great value. I got mine for 399. And you get a lot for it. As previously stated, It is not just a VR headset but also has a computer inside to play it's own QUEST VR games. Meaning it doesn't need a separate Game PC like other VR headsets. Keep in mind the "computer" in the Quest VR is based on a mobile chipset, so it's not powerful or comparable to a Gaming PC, or even the PS4, and that means the VR games for the Quest are much more simple graphically but it still great value for what you're spending and getting. I personally have not tried any Quest VR games because I got the Quest to link it to my Game PC which has the hardware to play real and more complex VR games for the PC.Cons:-This is a big one. It's uncomfortable. The PS4 VR was so comfortable though it's cumbersome with the cables connecting it to the PS4. Every VR headset requires some cables to a PC or a game console like the PS4. The Occulus Quest, because it has it's own computer built in doesn't need cables unless you use the Occulus Link cable to attach it to a PC. But the problem with the Quest is, after about 1 or 2 hours, I can feel my cheeks hurting. The reason is the design is front heavy, putting all the weight upon your cheeks and face, instead of the Halo design of other more expensive VR headsets. You get what you pay for. So comfort is a big negative for me. But it is 399.-Software set up and ease of use. I mainly use the Quest to link it to my Game PC and this requires a Link cable, and the Occulus software which turns the Occulus Quest functionally into an Occulus Rift S headset. The software has problems and is buggy. The installation has some errors and I have to manually start the Occulus server software every time I want to link it to my PC. I only solved this bug because I googled it and not many will be able solve this bug. It's not a big hassle but the software is not polished. This is why it's called BETA software meaning it's not finished. If you only play Occulus Quest games, then you don't have to deal with this. But I mainly got the Quest to link it to my PC. So it's kind of a hassle but I deal with it. The bigger problem is the poor comfort and ergonomics.Who is this VR Quest for?I think the Occulus Quest is for those who want an introductory easy to use stand alone VR headset for a low price of 399 for the 64 GB model.  I haven't played any Quest VR games but there is an Occulus store that has a decent selection of simple VR games. There are also free apps that enable you to watch netflix or amazon prime movies with it.It is also for those who want a cheap vr headset to play PC VR games via the Occulus Link. The Occulus Rift S is unavailable or sold out, and other options like the HTC Cosmos are more expensive. The downside of the Occulus Quest is it is uncomfortable, and the Occulus software to link the Quest to the PC is beta and buggy.But I use the Occulus Quest almost every day for a few hours. It works well but my cheeks ache but I put up with it because I enjoy VR gaming.Because of the reasonable price, I recommend the Occulus Quest for it's versatility and value but it is uncomfortable and painful to use because of it's front heavy design.
review_title: Honest review of the Occulus Quest 64 GB

one_reviews_text: This is a great headset. Running tethered to a computer or untethered, it has great levels of immersion. I presume most will be using it untethered as that's where it really shines: it has "eh" graphics but a feeling unlike any other VR as you don't have to worry about a cable. I recommend playing Superhot VR, as it's my favorite untethered game.However, I use this headset mostly with Oculus Link to my PC playing Half-Life: Alyx. It's great for that, and the OLED display means that dark black areas actually feel dark, as opposed to the Rift S and its LED backlit display, which doesn't do dark areas as well. However, it is my belief that Oculus Link adds some lag as opposed to a real PCVR headset, which makes me skew towards something else if you're going to exclusively be playing VR on a PC. I would get the original Rift, as I would hate playing on a non-OLED display, or the Vive (or obviously the Index, if you have that amount of money to throw around.) However, I can't really recommend this headset for exclusively tethered play, as the refresh rate is quite low compared to everything else and it has some lag. But it's a great thing to buy and show off to your friends who have never tried VR before, and it absolutely delivers a playable experience in Half-Life: Alyx. It's by no means a bad headset for tethered VR at all, I just would have gotten something else (if anything else would have been in stock - I bought it in late April, when the COVID-19 pandemic was in full force and basically every electronics item was sold out, including every VR headset known to man. I had to camp a competitor's website and buy it for in-store pickup.) Also, bear in mind if you want to use tethered VR, you should have a pretty beefy PC - I had to upgrade to a GTX 1080 after my old RX 480 was giving me stutters in Half-Life at low settings (paired with a 5820K @ 4.3GHz.)Also, I recently had an issue where it seems the left speaker is giving out on the headset, so fair warning. Luckily, support seems like they'll be taking decent care of me.All in all, it's a perfectly fine headset at a perfectly good price point that does both tethered and un-tethered VR pretty well. It's definitely the thing to buy if you want untethered VR, but also want to be able to plug in and play some Half-Life or something, but if you're looking for the most immersive experience and you have money to throw around, I'd definitely get the Index.

My boyfriend just surprised me with a quest the other day and I had never heard of it, but setup was easy and I was amazed!Unfortunately, the device is heavy and causes some head and face pain after wearing it for an extended period of time. Today is the third day I’ve owned it and after a short morning play session, I’m also experiencing some soreness in my neck. I’m hoping adding another strap and counter weight will help and that an adjustment period will ease the discomfort. Other than that, I love itUPDATE:I read some tips from other users on another website that recommended wearing the strap as close to the base of your skull as possible, almost touching your neck. After having adjusted the strap as recommended, it was noticeably more comfortable to wear the headset. Before, I was wearing the strap quite a bit higher on my head, so no wonder it was so uncomfortable. At the same time, I think a counter weight would still make it better

I remember my fascination with VR going way back to the time of the Sega Master System when it had the 3D glasses. It was clunky but cool at the same time. Well it wasn't really VR but to have a more interactive "realistic" experience where you are part of the game was how I pictured the future.Then came the 90s when Sega announced that they were coming out with a VR platform and I was just super excited and waited month after month reading EGM, GamePro, and Sega Visions magazines to see if there was any news or development on the VR. Unfortunately, it faded into vaporware. Let's ignore the Virtual Boy and the Stuntmaster because they were both garbage...Fast forward a decade (or two) later when VR went mainstream with the Vive, Rift, and PSVR. I was on and off in the PC Master Race so I grabbed the PSVR on launch day and was just amazed out how well executed and easy to setup it was. Plus the PSVR was also more affordable than the Vive and Rift a few years ago. The games were engaging, the experience just draws you in and I was able to do it all CONNECTED to my PS4. I will admit I was scared playing Resident Evil and playing one of my favorite racing games, Wipe Out is a whole different experience in VR. Problem was that:I had limited space in my game roomIt had to be tethered to the PS4 which takes the realism away in terms of movementPlaystation Move controllers, although effective were a bit awkward to useNow here we are with the introduction of the Oculus Quest which is a standalone VR unit with all the hardware build in. No console, no phone, no PC or any device that it had to be tethered to. A device where I can dive into VR anywhere! It actually sounded to good to be true. Let me tell you this... after using this for a month, I can confidently say that the future is here.I picked up the 128GB version at a local Best Buy on launch day. I'm sure it was a little overkill and I would have been fine with the 64GB but I didn't want to think about storage running out. Anyway, I took it out of the box, downloaded the app and some games while it was charging, did the initial setup and had some fun playing around with the tutorial.Speakers are kinda weak but not THAT bad. The headset is very responsive but it does get uncomfortable after using it for long periods of time. However, it was no more uncomfortable as the PSVR and the fact that I can play this without yanking my PS4 or being connected to another device is just amazing. Sure it doesn't have the latest hardware being powered by a Snapdragon 835 (yeah the same CPU as the Samsung Galaxy S8) but it is just so well executed.Finally loaded up Vader Immortal and then got a low battery warning because over an hour had gone by without me realizing it.I also purchased and bought Beat Saber. To this day, I use it as part of my morning work outs to get the blood running when I start my day. I've been hooked on the game and it brought me back to the old Dance Dance Revolution days except this is so much better. I just hope that continue to come out with more songs.Other game that I really enjoy playing is Robo Recall. It reminds of of those arcade shooters like Virtua Cop except you are actually in the game and you grab robots, rip them limb from limb and throw them around. This is definitely a must buy.A non-game app that I tried was Virtual Desktop. Virtual Desktop wghich is sort of like LogMeIn or other remote desktop apps, but in VR. I even fired out some YouTube videos through Chrome on my desktop but it was a little laggy. You are better off using the browser on the Oculus. Opened up Microsoft Outlook and was able to read through my emails. There a handful of instances where you can play some Steam VR games on a desktop using this, but I personally haven't tried it. I'm sure this application will be a lot better as the continue to develop this.I wanted to make sure I just wasn't going through a honeymoon phase because I remember being wowed and amazed right when I got the PSVR and now it's just collecting dust, and that's just mainly because it was sort of a hassle getting it setup.It's been a month and I have been using this every day. Like I mentioned, it doesn't have the best graphics due to hardware limitations but the games are well ported where it doesn't take away from the experience. Games do run smoothly and it's just so easy to just pick up and start playing.I can go on and on in this review but I can only describe the VR experience in so many words. You have to try it for yourself to fully understand how great the Oculus Quest is. The Quest is not perfect but it has taken me to a future that I dreamed of as a child.  What a wonderful time to be alive.
review_title: The Quest is not perfect but it has taken me to a future that I dreamed of as a child

one_reviews_text: I've used several VR headsets in the past but never owned one myself as I did not have space near my gaming PC to play; then along came the Quest and now I can play in my living room with no strings(or wires) attached. The experience is darn near that of a PC with just lower quality graphics, this loss of visual quality is easily made up by the portability and ease of access to this device. Right out of the box you are able to get up and running within minutes with no running of cabling or fiddling with the configuration on a PC. In addition, the ability to take this to a friend's house to show off the wonder of VR is something which cannot be matched by any VR solution to date.My only real complaint is the cost of games is a bit steep considering you are paying for what essentially is a downgraded port of already existing games; in addition, a number of these games (including the best seller on the system Beat Saber) are not cross buy. As such if you already own an Oculus product this is something you will want to factor into your decision. If you are a first time VR purchaser such as myself you will likely not have an issue with this.Overall I would recommend this headset to anybody interested in getting started with VR as well as those with some experience who want a way to move out of their PC room while playing or as a way to show off VR to those who have yet to try it.
review_title: Fantastic jump into VR for first time buyers!

one_reviews_text: Due to its weak, old chipset, same as Samsung Galaxy S8, the graphic suffers terribly and plenty of lag. The PS2 graphic gaming is perfect for adults that have not fully grown out of cartoon phase. If you have a normal mental development and are a fully grown adult, get a PCVR instead from Amazon, you get to play Racing, Flying, and FPS simulation. But if you love cartoons and lags, this is the VR headset to get.
review_title: Cartoon Gaming for Adults, the Best !

one_reviews_text: This is my second VR headset and intended upgrade to the PSVR which I've had for a few years. Loved the PSVR but wanted to try roomscale and higher resolution without getting too carried away in price. I also wanted something capable of playing AAA titles like Half-Life Alyx and Fallout 4 VR. I have a compatible cable and PC but have not had time to try those games yet. I may update this review later to discuss my thoughts on how this handles high-end games. For now, let's jump into my impressions after a few days of use. This review will mostly be valuable to people with PSVR considering venturing into PC VR gaming.SET-UP: There really isn't any hardware set-up required beyond charging the headset (about 2 hours) and putting batteries in the controllers. Functionality set-up is done via smart phone. It seemed like this was going to be an easy task until I got to the part of connecting it to wi-fi which is a requirement before you can use the headset. I spent about 2 hours fighting to get it to connect. I was entering what was absolutely the correct password for my wi-fi and it kept saying I had the incorrect password. It was getting infuriating to the point where I was about to just box it up and return it. I emailed Oculus's support and they came back about 15 hours later saying to try re-configuring my router from WEP to WPA2. I haven't messed with my router since I set it up about 7 years ago so had to go through another 2 hours of research, downloading the software and getting it switched over. Of course that also meant setting a new password which required me to update the dozen devices I have in the house to the new PW. PIA! But anyway, after 2 days of swear words and tech fighting, it worked and I got connected! Hooray! Oh, wait. Not so fast. Now it's updating the firmware and would just stop at about 98% after hours of updating. So now it's back to the internet. That's where I found that set-up from my smartphone wasn't complete because I didn't watch some safety video. Aaarrhgg!!!! Finished the video and then my phone sent the signal to my device that I was finally allowed to use it and it finished the update. So...set-up. Terrible if you go into it blind. Piece of cake if you read this review first. You're welcome.OPERATION: Once you finally get this thing on, the immediate experience is stunning. Setting up room scale will blow your mind. You basically paint your boundaries on the floor and it builds a wall exactly where you marked it. Then you simply do not run into anything because it gives you advanced warning. Spectacular technology! The controllers are comfortable and simple to use, much more intuitive and natural feeling than move controllers. The navigation/orientation room is fun to look at and navigate. Pretty neat display panel for the store. You can walk around the room in your defined space and it feels very natural like you're actually there. Just make sure your cats aren't in the room and you don't step on them like I did. Sorry, Skylar.GRAPHICS/IMMERSION: Compared to the PSVR, the graphics are definitely noticeably better. Much brighter, crisper and less screen door. The OLED & higher resolution makes a big difference. That said, don't go into it thinking it's going to look like a 4K movie because it's still VR. The tech just isn't there yet to make it look like you're on Pandora from Avatar. It looks pretty good but temper your expectations realistically. VR is still mostly about immersion and this headset does an incredible job of it. The first game I purchased and tried was Vader Immortal and it did not disappoint. On PSVR, the most similar experience would be Batman Arkum VR. Only with Vader, you can actually move, not just teleport. That and it's visually much cleaner and lifelike.COMFORT: Here's where the star comes off. I didn't knock a star off for the set-up because the review is for a functional headset. I try not to let set-up experiences impede review of the actual product. However, the comfort of this headset is not the best. I was actually shocked at the laziness of the design. It's just side Velcro straps and one poorly placed strap on the top. This causes all of the weight to shift to your face. And since this is a heavier headset since it's basically got it's own onboard computer and power supply, it gets very cumbersome after about 30 minutes of use. It puts quite a bit of pressure on your cheeks, nose and around the eyes. However, there simple aftermarket bands available on Amazon that basically adds a horizontal strap across the head that apparently completely solves the problem. Again, it's just amazing to me that Oculus skimped out on this very simple and very cheap extra step that would make their device perfectly fine for extended use.I will update this review once I have experience using it tethered to a gaming PC. From what I've read from other users, it's on par if not better than the Oculus S in those regards. But overall, my conclusion is for the price, the bump in graphic quality and the deep immersion of the roomscale, the Quest is definitely worth buying and is probably the best available VR experience on the market from a value & investment perspective. The comfort issues are solved with a $15 strap and the initial set-up woes I encountered likely don't happen for most people. And if they do, you now have my experience to get you through it.

I just got my Quest last week and have been having a blast with it. I'm fairly new to VR and don't have a PC so this was pretty much my only option other than PSVR but I had decided on the Quest due to supposed better tracking and no wires was just too hard to pass up.Pros:*The inside-out tracking is very impressive, rarely does it lose track of where I am within my guardian zone or where my controllers are*A lot of games available right away*The immersion into these worlds is hard to describe to people without them actually trying it out but you get lost in them fairly quickly.*Price is good for a VR headset that can do what this can doCons:*While it's cheap for a VR headset, it's certainly not easily affordable at $400 minimum*Games generally range from $15 up to $40, with a few free ones and some demos (why this is a con below)*A lot of these games are fun but feel more like technical demos that after a few hours of play may lose their appeal*The recommendation is for at least 6.5' x 6.5' of room. It was surprisingly hard to find that much space in our house. You can do it with less but there are some games that require a bit more movement but this hasn't been too much of an issue*My overall worry is that after a while the "wow" factor will disappear and if the games don't actually have a story or lasting appeal the Quest (or perhaps VR in general) could go the way of the Wii or the Kinect; a novel, cool idea that was nothing more than a gimmick or fad.

Wow.  When VR first hit the scene it was a) too expensive, b) required a hefty investment into a upper mid-range to high end PC and c) image quality was low (due to resolution / performance trade offs).  The Occulus Quest makes all the proper improvements and design trade-off's to bring VR to the masses.  It offers a full 6 degrees of freedom (tilt, yaw,  rotate and 3 degrees of translation freedom) normally reserved to externally tracked head sets.  The device is truly stand alone yet offers the ability to link to a PC for PC level apps and games.  Wireless (without a PC) to simplify usage.  The inside-out tracking means no external light boxes to setup, no extra hardware.  Literally, slap it on your head, grab the controllers, define a play area and done... you are in VR.If there is any complaint of this headset would be that because it contains it's own processor, memory, and battery all that comes with some weight and it is front heavy and can become a little uncomfortable after long game sessions.  Minor annoyance when you consider what you get.

The quest has a long list of games that will run on it without being plugged into anything.  You just download it from the store using the Quest or your phone with Oculus app and run.However... with a long enough USB cable and the right hardware you can run Oculus Rift S games as well off of your PC.  Just connect your Quest to your PC and run the Oculus link software and you can run games using your PC's power (make sure you have a good machine with a good graphics care).But wait... there's more ;-)  If you have Steam you can run SteamVR from the Oculus store via Oculus Link (just like a Rift) and then you can run Steam VR games like  Half Life Alyx, Skyrim VR, or Fallout 4 VR.The ONLY caveat is that you need a USB C connector on your PC AND that still might not work.  Some motherboards will support this and others do not.  I have a nice machine (I9, 32GB, RTX2080) and it would not work through the front USBC port.  It DID work great through the RTX2080's USB C port though and that is good enough for me).The link is still beta and while it works once up and running there is a little bit of trial and error to get the right workflow.  Start up the Quest unplugged... then start the Oculus app.  THEN connect through the USB... and then allow the link software to run.First time you run run the Steam VR from your PC.  After that you should be able to run it from the Quest itself but only after you set up the link.Not horrible but it can be a little fickle sometimes but once it runs there is normally never any problems.  It's quite good.
review_title: Best of both worlds.. or should I say three worlds?

one_reviews_text: This is an initial review and may be updated if Ocuclus lives up to the warranty.  The device worked great for the first two weeks I had it.  Easy to set up, easy to use, and I enjoyed the games. (I got great exercise from a couple of games.) Only thing I really had an issue with: virtually none of the apps I use on the Go are available on the Quest.  So if I wanted to attend a virtual concert or sport event on Oculus Events or NextVR I have to pull out the Go.  After two weeks the device died. No longer charges at all and there really is no guidance on their support page on what to do in this situation.  I submitted a trouble ticket to Oculus asking for assistance so this will be a test of their warranty and support.  If it gets fixed/replaced I'll update my review.

I'm a VERY technical person, but I had no interest in dedicating a computer and a zillion wires to VR; it seemed like the technology wasn't ready for prime time.  Until now.The Quest is essentially an all-in-one gaming console based entirely in VR.  It works beautifully--and simply--and the launch games are very good.Setup is simple, battery life is as predicted, and the gameplay is quick and responsive.The only drawback really is that you need a large-is space to play.  You CAN play in a small space (and we do) but the thing really comes alive when you can stretch your legs!  (Some folks would say that it's slow to charge--about a minute spent charging for each minute of play--but honestly I think you'll find that you need the break.)Not cheap, but not outlandishly priced. Feels like you are buying a bit of the future at a pretty decent price.
review_title: Finally, a VR set accessible to non-nerds and mere mortals.

one_reviews_text: *Update*Ok. I found some games I like.  They aren't the shoot um up ones.. I'm playing the Beat Saber and Synth Riders games.  Now those are worth the money, for me.  Still disappointed in the resolution of the other games compared to the tethered games but I'll keep this for the workout I'm getting with these two games.  Hopefully more will come in the near future!Original:The Go was neat for the first 24 hrs.. then its very limited.  So took it back and bought the Quest when it finally came in stock.. that is better but the games SUCK!  They are VERY limited.. the graphics are terrible.. there are only a few games out there in Jan 2020 and even tho they get 4.9 stars they are terrible 3rd person games where you're not even IN the game.. one in particular is MOSS where you WATCH a mouse go around  and do things...  did you read that right..  you WATCH the Mouse do things!  I didn't spend about $500 to watch a mouse do things!  When I went to the Rift site I was amazed!  Now they have games!!  Driving games are crazy on the rift.  Its like you would find on the XBOX or PS4.. they don't have anything like that for the Quest!  I am very disappointed.  I'm trying to figure out if I can get my MACBOOK to work with the new Link but its not looking like it.  I'm bummed that this is so limited.  I haven't actually found a game that I am willing to keep on this thing.  Now to get true gaming do I need to buy a gaming PC and a Rift so I can really get true VR?  Its definitely not this thing.  Before you buy try going to the Oculus app and looking at the choices of games.
review_title: First bought the Go now this.. probably taking back.  Disappointed *UPDATED*

one_reviews_text: UPDATE:  Oculus support finally resolved my issue after making me jump through multiple hoops. Still deducting one star due to making it so hard on customers to get decent support.ORIGINAL REVIEW:  Ordered my Quest directly from Oculus. Rating here because more people will likely see it.One star purely because of their VERY poor customer support. Had an issue day 1 (app related), submitted a support request online, they responded asking for more information. I responded to their request with the information they needed. Six days later I still haven't heard back so I log in and check the ticket. It has been closed and marked "resolved." I go back to the headset to see if it was indeed resolved, and it was not. I then initiated an online chat and the lack of support I received there was mind boggling. Basically they just kept telling me I was out of luck (on something that should have been a very easy fix). They finally offered to escalate it to email support, which I said I had already tried and had the request closed out for no reason, with no response. The support person just kept talking in circles and would not (or could not) answer my direct questions.I have a Rift and a Quest, hardware is okay, but just pray you never have to contact support. I will definitely not be recommending Oculus to anyone, based solely on the lack of support when needed.

The VR gets 5 stars it's an amazing piece of technology.  However i bought these for my two daughters and for them to play with each other they each have to have a Facebook account. As parents we decided that social media is not appropriate nor safe for our kids at this time so for Oculous to promote the selling towards 13 and up. And not let people know that you have to have facebook in order to play with people in the same house or just your school friends is Wrong. 13year olds should not have to have a social account to play with each other. Especially since predators use social media to find their victims. By you forcing parents to get their kids an account. Just so they can play I feel like you should also be responsible and held accountable for the actions of the predators that are out there using Facebook to hunt for their innocent under age victims. If you are a parent who agrees that your kids should not have to be on social media to play. Please write to Oculus and Facebook.
review_title: Must have facebook to play with others. Regardless of age.

one_reviews_text: Do you want to walk around inside a virtual world and use your hands? If so, then this is the cheapest and easiest way to achieve that. For some people $400 will be too much for the current level of VR content compatible with Quest. Some people should wait a couple more years for a lower price point with a more mature ecosystem. For even more adamant early adopters, a full-fledged PC VR system ($1600) is a better investment to see all that VR developers have made (e.g. Oculus Rift, Valve Index, HTC Vive, etc.). That's not me, but some of my friends want to be at that level of commitment.How does Quest work? Like much of the 2019 VR generation, the headset employs inside-out tracking; it houses four built-in cameras which track your controllers' and your headset's positions relative to the stuff/walls of your room.What do I think after using Quest for a few weeks? I think it's really amazing. I show it to people and they giggle like little kids when they see the magic of it. My wife and kid love playing Beat Saber. I like seeing all kinds of VR experiences.How long could you stay in there? I would say that spending 30-60 minutes at a time is a full session. After that my head starts to feel a little sore. Also the battery only lasts 2.5 hrs and requires a couple hours to charge. The controllers need batteries to be replaced/recharged every dozen hours of use or so.How realistic is it? Not very realistic--it is comparable to Wii graphics and locomotion is still a problem yet to have a marketable solution.How good is the content / game library? The software ecosystem is still maturing, so don't expect to spend hours reinventing some Oasis-type second-life-esque world. The experiences/games cost around $20, which isn't too bad if you have disposable income and only require a few games at a time. So far there haven't been any sales in the official Oculus market. There is also a sideloading software source that is great for customizing beat saber (needs you to plug into a desktop computer).

I had never so much as tried a VR headset, and I bought my Quest within days of trying out my boyfriend's. (I won't lie; it was "BeatSaber" that hooked me!)It's easy to use; setting it up with my Wifi using the Oculus app was a snap, and so was downloading games. The controls are very intuitive and comfortable, as well.The sound quality is very good without headphones (and I don't like using headphones when I'm wearing it, as I already can't see what's going on around me ... I at least want to be able to hear!). Video quality is good but not razor-sharp. I expect there will be a lot of progress on this front in the next version.The game selection currently is decent and seems to be expanding rapidly. "BeatSaber" is a favorite of mine and also a great workout, but my kids particularly like "Job Simulator" and "Sports Scramble." "SuperHot" is really fun but you need more space than I currently have in my living room to play it (I'm afraid I'm going to punch my TV by accident ...)
review_title: My first VR experience, and I'm hooked

one_reviews_text: I'll make this short and sweet - BAM! Like a tiny disposable paper cup filled with fresh honey. I was riding the Oculus wave since the very beginning, you best bet your top and bottom dollars that I threw some money into the Kickstarter to nab myself a Devkit 1 (or DK1, as the cool peeps prefer to call it, of which I am one). Then I received the CV1 and - BOOOOM - mind blown! I was in the game, I was out of the game.  But man, that dang wire was bringing me down, tethered to my desktop. I felt imprisoned - I felt that every turn I made had to be greeted with a counter-turn to undo the twisting of the cable, and I'd still end up with a squiggly spaghetti noodle of a wire. It made me anti-wholesome. It made me sad. I had excessive trouble sleeping at night, lying wide-eyed awake in the darkness, gripped with fear of the thought that I had unknowingly forgotten to make one or two counter-turns earlier in the day and welp, that'd be it. I'd be stuck with an oinky oinky pig tail cable for the rest of my times.But the thought of the Quest was the fuel for my aching soul. I erected a shrine in the depths of my grandmother's closet, a large poster of the Quest I printed at Kinko's neatly taped to the wall, sitting over a line of fresh pumpkin spice candles arranged in a semicircle. And the day arrived when IT arrived. Freedom. Absolute. Freedom. Liberation. No cable. I could spin; I could spin to my heart's content! I could jump, I could leap, I could roll up my pant legs and dance a dance across the roof! Nary a neighbor could stop me either, not old-lady Mary with her crinkly, somber expression and foul-mouthed disdain towards "this ***** doomed resurgence of VR", not even mr. postman Jackson, who had a regrettable outing with a Virtual Boy in a darker period of his life, one of which still sends shivers down his spine (and his cockatiel's). For gumbo's sake, even little Timmy, skipping along the curb with that goofy grin, clutching so tightly to his LABO VR that his hands turn a pale, cold white, careful not to loosen his grip for fear of losing his cardboard-laden Switch to the hard, cold pavement below. No one could sever this surging elation, this sudden virtual delight; I was a king. Wait no, I was an emperor. No. Yeah, I was just a king.Now please let me tell you some other pertinent details. The Quest plugs wraps its smooth, silky head straps around my fuzzy head for, say, 2 hours at a time, at which the depletion of the battery requires a recharge, and I become sad. But please don't worry about me, or yourself for that matter, for Oculus graciously included a super long charging cable so you can still charge and play. It's a USB-C. I think the C stands for "Cool". The screen is so sharp that it'd do better on the SATs than I did. I ask, "Dear Quest, how is your screen door effect?" and it replies in a deep, boisterous laugh, "SDE? What, do tell, is that?". Quest doesn't want to admit it, that he's still susceptible to SDE , but when it's this minimal, I honestly cannot blame him for not noticing. You will need many, many kilobytes if you wish to consume lots of photography or moving pictures or big games, but 64,000,000 kilobytes will suffice for most. I demanded 128,000,000 kilobytes so I can run my Unities and my Unreals and download salt-crusted fish recipes and lots and lots of cat photographs to share with dour passengers on the public transport. Oh, the Quest doesn't work well in the dark, but I don't either - I prefer to be asleep in the dark, so I think that's why. You'll need "reading" lighting for the Quest to perform optimally, concerning tracking, so you may want to consider purchasing a lamp (please don't forget a lightbulb) or a large flashlight or another form of illumination for the room you anticipate you'll be wearing your Quest in. About light - you can play outside in the sun, but don't expose the lens to the sun, it was built in an a closed-off factory and can't handle the joy of bright sunshine and fresh air.The other night I was battling Darth Vader in my bedroom. And then I was slashing away at colorful floating cubes with lightsabers while euphorically slithering my body to some delectable rhythms. And then I was blasting aliens in outer space while training to become a Space Pirate. All in my bedroom. And then the next day my Quest finally arrived.I will leave you with a thought, and you may take this in any way you wish. I dance in front of my friends who still bow down to the tether. Stricken with a deep guilt and afraid they're unaware of the sublime life I live, I tirelessly try to convert them, to lead them to the warm lights and the greener pastures, a life where they too can dance freely without the unjust treatment of the tether. "But I'd prefer to face my TV while holding colorful spheres," they proclaim! "But I quite enjoy the feeling of having my feet caught between cables, the smooth texture of the wire as it slithers up my dry shins","I cannot leave the tether, for it grounds me, and without it, then how will I know who I am in this life, or the next?" They so easily make a travesty of my intentions, of my helping hand, but "Chill", I tell myself, "it's just a matter of time, until they too find their way in the Oculus. In the Quest." And I hope you do too. Diss the tether!
review_title: The Quest Has Made Me Believe in VR!

one_reviews_text: I own an Oculus Rift (PCVR), an Oculus Go, a GearVR, multiple Google Cardboard variants, and now a Quest.The Quest is hands down my favorite VR device. The freedom of wireless VR is not to be understated. My Rift currently has an overhead cable management system, but the sensation of no longer being tethered is incredible. Moving freely in games like Robo Recall and Space Pirate Trainer has unlocked new levels of play that I simply  didn't have before.The improved visuals are incredible, using Virtual Desktop I am able to comfortably read text and even write code for extended periods while wearing the headset.So far the experience has been nothing short of amazing. If you are new to VR or are looking to upgrade from your current setup, the Quest is the most compelling device on the market, and likely will be for many years to come.

I bought this from bestbuy because they had it for $40 cheaper.  Anyway, this is the vr headset to buy period. The only reservations I have about the headset is games.  So I have owned rift, Lenova vr, PlayStation vr and Oculus’s quest.  The quest is so simple and it works. Graphically you get about 85 percent of the graphics fidelity of the rift but with so much less hassle.  I just finished Vader imorttal an it looks great. I started up moss an that games looks great as well. My fears of gameplay have been eliminated.  The quest if games are made for the system will be the lead platform in my opinion.  The hassle free wireless headset is a game changer.I can only see this stuff getting better. To me this replaces a portable game device.  YouTube looks great as well.It is the real deal and delivers.
review_title: It is the real deal. Game changer do not want to go back to psvr or rift.

one_reviews_text: The Oculus quest is all I ever wanted in a VR headset. Coming from things like the Oculus GO and gear VR the quest seems light years ahead of those. The room scale tracking the lack of any wires is all amazing, I found my self getting sucked into VR in a way I never have before. That being said.The quest isn't for everyone. If you are expecting a PS4 Xbox one amazing 4k experience you may want to reduce your expectations a bit. VR is young and will be for a long time. The quest is a big leap forward sure but it is a long way from where it needs to be. The quest runs a mobile chip, which means graphics are far from being any where near what this generation of game systems offer, that being said they are impressive for what it's working on and I'm not a big graphics guy, so it doesn't matter to me, but it may to you. I would compare them to somewhere between PS2 and Xbox 360.Although the resolution sounds high when you blow it up to VR scale it's actually still low. The screen door effect is greatly reduced compared to something like gear VR but it's still there. Also the screens refresh rate is only 72 Hearts, my eyes have never been treated to a more premium VR experience but I'm told that to some this  ruins the experience. Also games are very expensive for what they are, most in the $30.00 range. And while I did own a lot of Gear/Go games most are not available to me to redownload in many cases I would have to buy the updated quest versions all of which are more expensive the the Go version. So is life!All and all the quest is amazing, but VR is young, the product isn't perfect yet, no VR head set is. Just keep in mind where VR is at the moment before you buy this. I for my part love it though what Oculus managed to do here is amazing!

No warning, no nothing. Now if you want to add a friend, you have to link your account to facebook. I don't have a facebook account. It's against the rules to make a fake one. This was a rule they snuck in over the holidays without notification. Previously, you didn't have to have a facebook account to add a friend. Now you do. Just because facebook owns oculus doesn't make it okay to take away perfectly functional features just so that they can datamine everything I do. Very disappointed.

Our first oculus quest was such a hit at our house, that we ended up purchasing a second.  The first headset has worked almost flawlessly, with only occasional crashes and pixels. The second, however, seems to have a faulty sensor.  You can turn it on, but you see only a black screen, as if it thinks you've removed the headset.  This was worked around for several weeks by putting a piece of post-it note over the sensor.  Now, it has started doing this again and no amount of turning off and on, fiddling with sensor covering and light levels, or factory resetting has gotten us around the problem.  Unfortunately, our return period expired just before this became the most disappointing gaming equipment in our home.  Ours was purchased through BestBuy, but I wanted people to know that these are pretty commonly faulty.  The forums are full of people with the same problem we have with no chime in from Oculus with a resolution.
review_title: Awesome...unless you get one of the numerous lemons

one_reviews_text: I started out on Google Cardboard and worked my way up to Google Daydream, then the Oculus Go, and now the Quest. Here are my brief impressions of the Oculus Quest:- It's slightly heavier than the Go, but not too bad. I'm able to play for a full 2 hours and not feel any fatigue or pain. Adjusting the straps and positioning it on your head is KEY. Realistically, VR gaming sessions should be short'ish anyway (1 hr at a time, tops), to give your eyes a break and to rest (some of these games are a workout!).- Graphics and framerate are better than I expected. The Snapdragon 835 processor (same as Pixel 2) is overclocked, so it's more than just a "crappy" CPU as other reviewers put it.- The Guardian boundary system is cool, but currently a bit overly sensitive. If you're moving your hands quickly, the grid shows up too easily. Oculus is working on a fix for this, though.- Fully portable and no wires: this is the top selling point of this platform, and it's amazing. Yes, you're sacrificing some graphics quality compared to the Rift or any PC-based VR, but for many people, it's worth not having to worry about getting tangled up in a cord, or setting up sensors and making sure you're always in view of them.- Great for arcade-type games, interactive experiences, social apps, and more. But if you're looking for epic 40+ hour story-driven games, you're better off sticking to consoles.Overall, I think this thing is amazing and it's lived up to the hype!
review_title: Super quick review - GET THIS THING

one_reviews_text: Former PSVR owner here. Sold it to switch over the the Quest. So far, I can’t believe what this headset can do. Simply put, this is a device that can satisfy BOTH the newcomer and seasoned veteran. The launch lineup is pretty much entirely made up of ported titles but savvy vets don’t fret. As the old song goes “you ain’t seen nothing yet”. Finally, VR will hit the mainstream in a big way. This is the hardware that will take it there. The graphics are stellar, better than PSVR in my opinion. The tracking is nearly perfect. The controls are quickly learned and seeing a low res view of your surroundings when outside the play area through the headset is a feature not available until now. The guardian system is a total game changer. This allows you to play wherever you want and the fact that some games support kicking back in a recliner or even playing in bed is incredible. VR used to be complicated and cumbersome. The Quest has redefined VR as we know it making it as simple as sit in your favorite chair, put on the headset, and play. Casting support is great for chromecast and if you have an Apple ecosystem, the Oculus app even supports screen mirroring to Apple TV. I am so excited to see where Oculus devs take this device to. It’s looking like the perfect platform to catapult VR where it always wanted to be. Get one, you won’t be disappointed. Believe the hype, this is VR for the masses.

I've used the rift and windows mixed reality. The rift s and the mixed reality both use the same sort of idea (the S is pretty much the exact same) But oculus just does it better than my experience on lenovo and samsung.Games like robo-recall really don't look as good, but for the gains you get, it is really worth it. A lot of them like Superhot I couldn't tell a single difference. The biggest downside game-=wise, is that I can't use any of my steam games.Other things you lose are the ability to customize your home area (which supposedly is coming soon) and things like the ability to pop in another screen inside your VR game and for instance like play a movie like you can on the rift. Those are things I miss but are just small niceties.I really recommend you give it a try. This is really that first time sometone could get a full VR experience without much hassle or owning a powerful computer.
review_title: Comparing to the rift and windows mr it's really a great achievement.

one_reviews_text: **May 30th updated**After owning my Quest for over a week I decided to return it. While the VR portion of it is spot on and super cool. For me the app ecosystem and locked down android interface just wasn't cutting it. It lost it's novelty for me fast and I can see that in 3 months I'll use the Quest much less. Making it a 500 dollar closet toy ill bring out to show friends occasionally. Most of the games that have been released for it have been out for years and are being sold for a significant markup which turns me off. I did side load it with software called side quest. However you might as well just use your phone since most phone apps do not function well in VR. Overall I still think this is a fantastic device and if you want to check it out go for it. My biggest gripes are the battery covers on the controller slide off when doing fast movements, audio can cut in and out and get garbled for whatever reason (pretty sure it's software related), wireless capabilities are kind of hit and miss. (blue tooth audio is spotty, can only cast to your phone or chrome cast, sending videos you record are a pain, and there are more TV viewing apps than I know what to do with. The VR portion of the quest is amazing! It was everything else that turned me off.This was my first VR headset and i'm blown away. After doing a lot of research on available VR headsets out there I decided the Quest was the most likely fit for me due to the wireless capabilities. I bought a Oculus Quest 128gb on launch day at Best Buy. After the initial setup of the device which is fairly simple. Download the app on your phone and pair it to the Quest. You run the "First Steps" app and it gave me goosebumps. The immersion and feeling you get when you play this thing is spectacular. Picking up and throwing objects with your hands, pulling levers, moving, dancing, slashes and more are all realistic motions the Quest can easily track.  The guardian boundary system is fluid and responsive all though maybe a tad too sensitive depending on the size of your play space. The camera mode when outside of the guardian system is low res and black and white. Not ideal for walking around the house but good enough for adjusting your area or grabbing your drink or something. The games that i've played so far are fantastic but wish there was more apps that could be used. There is a Netflix, Youtube, and a few other video streaming apps available. Hopefully this will change over time along with more multiplayer online or co-op games. My biggest complaints about the system is the battery covers on the controllers tend to slide off which can be fixed by a rubber band or something. The battery on the headset dies quickly (about 2-3 hours like everyone else says)  but this isn't a huge deal for me because it's usually time for a break by then anyway. It does come with a plethora of demos for you to try which is awesome since most of us have no idea what kind of VR games we are in to. Vader Immortal is like being in a real life Star Wars movie. Space Pirates Trainer is super fun VR version of space invaders and Racket Fury is also a blast that has multiplayer (ping pong). The simulated surround audio is decent for what it is and has a built in mic for party chat that will work for most people, however there is a audio jack output for those that want to use something better. The 64 gb version should be plenty for most people as the games i've downloaded are usually about 2.5Gb or less. I opted for the 128 just for the extra storage down the road just in case games start getting bigger or something. I would say the controller tracking is spot on about 96% of the time. I usually run into issues during ping pong when the headset can't pick up where the controllers are at because i'm not facing the right way or moving too fast. The OS the Oculus uses looks to be a modified version of the android OS but heavily closed down and with a totally different app store. It does have live streaming options to your Facebook account but this doesn't really seem to be totally necessary unless you do that sort of thing. I didn't understand the screen door effect that you read about until I started playing this thing but it makes sense and is true. However it is not noticeable in darker environments and really is a non-issue overall. The graphics in most games seem to vary by developer and are not comparable to xbox/ps4/PC. However, I would say they generally look fine and everything plays so well that it's really a non-issue for me. Could they be better? Sure! Does it turn me off the device. Heck no! With continued developer support and a steady stream of games and content for us to devour this device should be an absolute game changer in the VR industry. There is nothing like this out there and it caters to all kinds of people!

I like my Oculus Quest however I will be selling it due to the fact that Mark Zuckerberg is going to make it mandatory to have a Facebook account to even use an oculus. I HATE Facebook with a passion, and not even the Oculus will change that! I've been usting an Oculus for many years now and this is a deal breaker for me.
review_title: mandatory Facebook account is going to be REQUIRED!

one_reviews_text: So every year we go to an international convention and check out all the VR stuff, it’s supposed to be leading edge. And every year we were and felt Meh about the VR experience. Then quest....... my son wanted one for his birthday and I was apprehensive because leading up to the quest it was lack luster. We asked questions online and watched gameplay, we asked the Best Buy guy and then we demo’d one. From the min I put the headset on to the first steps interactive game to introduce you to the controls it is an immersive experience. Best experience I’ve had on VR and wireless. Couple this with a great noise cancelling headset like Bose and look out! It’s an amazing experience. The whole family has enjoyed and our only gripes are #1 the batteries only last 2 hours and then recharge and #2 we only have one quest. We will be purchasing another, it feels real when your playing. You don’t get sick from motion sickness because the frame rate and refresh rate are fantastic. The oculus touch remotes are inntuitive and easy to learn quickly. The “richies plank” game is amazing it feels like you are on a plank way above in the sky. Robot recall is immersive and graphics are amazing, can’t wait to try other game titles. The theater mode looks and feels like your in a theater. Amazing def buy one it’s worth every penny.

Pros:Good clarity screens with good resolution and black levels with decently vibrant colors.Mechanical IPD adjustmentTracking works wellNo computer / portability obviouslyCons:Pass through could be clearerAudio changes were a big let downHaving to buy games I've already paid for on Rift (beat saber, moss etc...) sucksConclusion: I sold my OG rift months ago to get this and am very pleased with this device. Display is always subjective to the user, their head, their pet peeves, so take it for what it is, but I actually found the display clearer than the OG rift and easier to dial in the sweet spot than Rift S probably due to no IPD adjustment. for pure realism it won't beat the rift S, but everything else more than makes up for what corners visually were cut. The tracking was better than Rift S at least based on my limited testing of Rift S... ~30mins. I would recommend those with a OG rift and on the fence with Rift S, either get the Quest or wait for the index or something as I just wasn't impressed by it when compared to my old one and the Quest is pretty close except for playing something like Stormlands that won't be on Quest.
review_title: Really nice device, display is good, sound is meh

one_reviews_text: Seriously - you can't even have a guest profile. You get one save for each game and that is it!! There are currently no adding second profiles.  This has to be the biggest Facebook failure in history.  I bought this for my kids for Christmas (note...kids...plural...as in...more than one) for them to SHARE!!! only to find out they are not actually allowed to share it by company who makes the product.  My dissapointment is exponential.  From what I've read the only way to share it is to do a factory reset each time you want to switch to a different account - which means you have to buy each game twice if you want each user to be able to play a single game with multiple people.  No way I would have bought this had I known.
review_title: You can't share it or have multiple profiles

one_reviews_text: The Good:1.) Setup / Installation is a breeze. Take it out, plug it in, download the app, put it on, and you are instantly ready to go. There is no computer, no setup, no anything. It feels like a console experience. I was up and running in less than 15 minutes. It felt like bringing a PS4 or Xbox home and just 'plug it in and go'.2.) The first 15 minutes experimenting with the tracking in a 3d enviroment is a life-changing experience. Can't really put it into words honestly, you just need to experience it. If you were waiting to jump on the VR train - I have 0 regrets about the purchase, this is absolutely where to get in. Those first 15 minutes are transformative and magical. If you've already experienced VR, then this isn't really a pro for you.2.) True Wireless Freedom is the single biggest advantage to the Quest. You don't have to worry about wires, it lets you PAINT your own boundary lines and remembers where that is. It's an elegant solution to one of the biggest challenges to VR done right. Having an untethered VR experience really takes it to the next level. This is the biggest hurdle that has kept me from shelling out hundreds for a VR experience. The Quest has no limitations when it comes to wires.3.) The motion tracking for the controllers is absolutely on point. It feels just like the high end Vive to me. There has yet to be a SINGLE INSTANCE in over 8 hours of playing where I felt like the tracking was inconsistent or off via Beat Saber or the built in demos. One of the big caveats with 'wireless' VR setups is that the tracking was garbage, the Quest does NOT have that problem, the tracking is fantastic, and feels like a fully featured VR setup.4.) The graphics on display are definitely a few steps below what you might expect from a $1000 computer, but its not a huge difference, there are a lot of videos comparing the quests graphics to others, and it varies from App to App - the particle effects in Beat Saber for example are quite different, but I actually like the Quests minimal approach better. Overall? I was thoroughly impressed with what the Quest could do graphically without having a PC behind it.The Bad1.) Limited Apps - You can only play VR apps that exist on the Quest store. The launch line up is killer though, but moving forward, this could become an issue. If your favorite VR game is not supported, this could be an issue.2.) Battery Life is only 2 hours, you'll need to invest in a 3rd party battery to charge on the go for extended play sessions. Worth noting you CAN charge the device while wearing it, but your back to the tether now.3.) PC Compatibility - In order to mod applications and games, your going to need to get into side-loading. You lose a lot of the freedom you have with a traditional PC setup - things like custom songs in Beat Saber can't really be done YET - but the Quest is going to be big, so I'd predict this stuff is coming, might just have to learn how to mod your Quest to do it.4.) The built in Streaming features are a bit iffish currently. My Chromecast did not work, so I'm going to upgrade to the latest generation and see if that fixes the issue, I presume you'll also need a strong WiFi connection to get streaming done right. The build in offerings did not work well, showing it on a cellphone was like looking at a pixelated block, but again, might be due to my wifi.If you have yet to experience VR, I simply cannot recommend the device enough. It's a game changer.
review_title: True wireless freedom with solid graphics and fantastic tracking

one_reviews_text: Whether you are a VR veteran, or this is your first virtual reality headset, this thing is AWESOME! I have used the original Oculus Rift headset, and own a Playstation VR system and Oculus Go. This is by far the most impressive VR headset I have tried! I was very skeptical when I first heard Oculus was going to release an all in one headset. I figured the graphics would be bland, and the game lineup would be kind of sub par.Boy was I wrong! I preordered the 64gb version after owning the Oculus Go for about 6 months. The Go is an OK headset if you like watching alot of movies. If you're more into gaming though, it left alot to be desired. After picking the Quest up and booting it up for the first time, I was absolutely speechless! My wife, who by the way was annoyed that I was spending $400 on yet another headset tried Beat Saber out about an hour after I got it, and I almost had to fight her to get my headset back, lol. (She still plays that game daily by the way).After letting my kids try out Rec Room, and first steps, they were left with the biggest smiles on their face. Now, with all that said, here are the pros and cons...Pros - Unbelievably sharp display! Whether playing games, or watching youtube or netflix, this is one of the better looking VR displays.  - Very strong launch lineup of games. Games range from $10 to $30. I highly recommend Beat Saber, Super Hot, and Vader Immortal.  - No wires, initial setup is super simple, and takes just minutes!  - The touch controllers are great! I have yet to experience any tracking issues, and they feel great in the hands.Cons - The battery life in the headset is a bit short. 2-3 hours. However, it does come with a rather long charging cable that you can use to charge while you play.  - You eventually have to take the headset off and return to real life. Haha.Yep, those are the only cons I can think of.Seriously, pics online and videos on youtube just don't do this headset justice! This is an absolute MUST buy if you are a gamer, just love interacting with people online, or like to kick back and watch movies or youtube. (Watching videos is like watching on a theatre screen)! Just stop reading this and buy it! Oh, and if you are questioning whether to get the 64gb or 128gb... The 64 is cheaper, and has MORE than enough storage space for your games!
review_title: The MUST have VR headset! It's a BEAST!

one_reviews_text: Lets start with the most impressive about this product: its build quality. In the short amount of time I've had this thing its been through some less than desirable situations and still works perfectly. It has been thrown (not dropped but thrown) on the ground and still works fine. The controllers punched walls and ceilings and the tracking works fine. If you are worried about the build quality or durability there is no need to.The comfort of it is great for about 15-20 minutes but then the back of your head starts to get very sore. this is not a huge deal because you can put a t-shirt or small towel in between your head and the back of the straps.the only reason this product doesn't get a 5 star review is because of the games. don't get me wrong, they are super fun and re-playable (especially beat saber) but they are a bit pricey for what you get. I know that developing VR games is harder than normal games but the pricing is still and issue for me. I think the worst offender of this is job simulator, for twenty dollars you get 4 ten segment long levels, I wouldn't be complaining about this if the levels were all fun and interesting but it is very boring.now here are some of my recommendations for games.1 beat saber- 25$-this game is super fun and a pretty good work out on harder levels. when you start playing, I suggest playing every level to see which songs you enjoy. then keep playing those songs until you can reliably beat them on expert. after that you can play almost any song you want and have a good time.song recommendations:Beat saber in category onerum'n bass  in category 2crab rave  in EXTRAS categorypop stars in EXTRAS category.there are ways to get custom songs using a program called "side quest" look it up if you are fairly tech savvy and want to get more out of your Oculus Ques2 gun club -20$-this game has lots of different guns, each having many accessories you can equip.there is lots of fun to be had by making guns with 16 laser pointers or carefully making the perfect weapon.  this game has modes for every body and then a second set on levels that take place in a world war two setting. it is very fun and has a game mode for every one.3 SUPER HOT -30$-this is super hot but in vr. let me tell you, having played both of these games, they play completely differently but both are equally fun.  the premise is this: bad guys are red, objects you can pick up are black, and time stops if you don't move.so say an enemy shoots at you, if you stop moving you can plan your movements and dodge it. it may sound confusing but it makes sense while you play. when you beat the game you can go back through and beat it again but with a certain twist depending on what challenge you do. beating the game also unlocks endless mode which pits you against endless waves of red guys and puts you in different areas than in the campaign.tilt brush-20$- this game is very relaxing and you can pour hours into them. they are basically 3D painting simulators where you can choose what brush you want from 48 options, and any color you want, you are also able to edit the back round color and brightness and the lighting. if you have lots of spare time I suggest you get this game purely on the basis of how satisfying and relaxing it is.  gravity sketch is another option similar to this but 10$ more and has more advanced features.Of course the biggest difference between the quest and other vr headsets is that the quest is that the quest is standalone and needs no wires or a pc. This makes a huge difference in Emerson. It also heavily cuts down costs, not only is the quest the same price or cheaper but needs no expensive computer to run it, saving hundreds or possibly a thousand dollars. having no wires means you cant play for more than 2 hrs with out plugging it in to charge but this is not a huge deal because even with the cloth behind your head method your neck might get sore before that time. you can charge the head set while playing so this is still a viable head set for groups of people to use.WARNING: if you use this headset in direct sunlight it will cause the OLED screen to burn and ruin the headset, do not use it outside.Ending notesover all this product receives a 4.8 star review from me. it is nearly perfect and its only real flaws are from the developers that make games for it. I highly recommend buying this if you have the money. I purchased this from the official Oculus website only because it was out of stock on amazon. i left my review here so more people would see it and consider buy the oculus quest.
review_title: Extremely fun to use and well made.

one_reviews_text: I was first introduced to VR when I first bought a Google Cardboard for my phone.  For those who don't know, it was basically a cardboard box with special lenses that you put your phone in to, to give you a small taste of VR.  Being impressed by that, I jumped on board and made my first legit VR headset, the HTC Vive.  I was blown away!  It kept me occupied for years.  That is until our family went on vacation and upon returning, we had purchased a new home which meant taking down my HTC Vive setup which required taking down the precisely placed tracking cameras on my walls and all the wires that came along with it.  Since the move, I haven't touched the HTC Vive due to the initial set up process.  Even after things were all set up, after every play session, I would have to deal with all the wires cluttered around my computer and living room every time.  This just made the experience somewhat of a hassle.  So much a hassle that the HTC Vive has sadly been collecting dust since our move.  This is where Oculus Quest has come to the rescue!  I was somewhat hesitant of my purchase, but after reading all the early positive reviews and early gameplay comparisons between the Oculus Quest and higher end VR headsets, I decided to make the jump.  I am very pleased to say that the purchase did not disappoint not one bit!  Although the graphics can be a downgrade for some graphically intense counterparts from the HTC Vive, the ease of set up and the total freedom of being completely wireless more than makes up for it!  Games like Job Simulator, Superhot, and Rec Room look identical to being played on the HTC Vive, but games like Robo Recall (used software to play on HTC Vive) you can tell the difference due to the higher graphical requirements to play the game on the HTC Vive.  Despite this, I much prefer playing Robo Recall on the Oculus Quest.  VR is about the experience first and graphical fidelity second.  Even playing games like Robo Recall that look much prettier on a higher end VR device, the experience is where it's at!  Being able to move freely without any wires dodging bullets gives you total immersion.  Don't get me wrong, the game is not ugly by any means on the Oculus Quest.  It's still a very pretty game! The freedom of wires, ease of set up, and ability to take the Oculus Quest wherever you go is what makes this headset so amazing!  Plus, those without a PC do not need one for this headset!  This is for anyone and everyone.  Anyone who has yet to experience VR who doesn't want to go out and purchase a high end gaming PC plus a headset just to experience it, and even those who already have a gaming pc and a high end VR headset who want to experience total VR immersion and total ease of set up!  This is for anyone not tech savvy as well!  Again, this is VR to the masses.  Even my 6 and 7 year old can pick up and play this thing whenever they want!  A highly recommended product and in my book, a 10/10.

I bought this from Quest website. I have filed a return request on their support website, the ticket has been open for more than 7 days. Replied and no response.
